Character Creation

1. ROLL STAT SCORES

Your character has 6 attributes that define your character physically and mentally. These are Strength (Str), Dexterity (Dex), Constitution (Con), Intellect (Int), Wisdom (Wis), and Charisma (Cha). More on details are found in Chapter 2: Stat Scores.

Roll 3d6 for each of these Abilities to generate that score.

This should result in something similar to this:

Str: 13

Dex: 7

Con: 10

Int: 14

Wis: 11

Cha: 6

Bonfire is specifically balanced for you to roll 3d6 in order, with 10 being the average result but you’ll have the chance to modify these later so don’t worry too much if you have low scores.

2. RECIEVE CrP

Alright, you have your scores. Now it’s time to decide whether or not if you can reroll them. At this point you’re also going to determine how many Creation Points (or CrP, for short) you’ll start with. These CrP will be spent on modifying your character; buying them their skills and increasing their Scores. They may also be spent on rerolls at certain steps.

If you have no score over 13, or 2 under 6, you may choose to reroll for free. Your character just didn’t have it in him to go adventuring.

If that’s not the case and you still want to reroll your stats, you can but you receive 0 CrPs to work with and you’re stuck with your second set of Scores.

Even still, you may want to switch your stats around. This may be because you have almost the right stats but you have a specific character concept in mind. For instance, using the example stats in Step 1, your party may need a diplomatic character more than a strong character. In this case, it would really help to swap Strength and Charisma.

You can freely switch around your stats as need but, in that case, you only receive 25 CrPs.

If you switch only 4 of your stats, you receive 50 CrPs.

If you switch 2, you receive 75 CrPs.

And if you keep your stats the way they are, with no changes, you gain 100 CrPs to work with.

3. SELECT RACE

Your character’s race will change how they interact with the world and what they’ll be good and bad at so pick carefully.

Details are found in Chapter 3: Races so go there and pick one and come back here when you’re done.

4. CHOOSE YOUR ARCHETYPES

Your character’s class is made of two Archetypes combined.

You choose a Primary and a Secondary Archetype and pay the price in CrP for both based on your race’s Archetype Cost section. Descriptions of the different Archetypes are found in Chapter 4: Archetypes along with more details on how to combined them.

If you’ve chosen to reroll your stats and have no CrPs to work with, congratulations, you’re now in CrP debt and need to make it up by the end of Character Creation.

You must select two Archetypes before going further.

5. RECORD ARCHETYPE ABILITIES

This is more for Caster Archetypes, as they’ll head over to Chapter 12: The Weird to roll their starting spells but now is the time to record any free Skills, or Masteries you obtained free from your class choice, as well as Class Abilities

6. ROLLS FLAWS

All heroes have flaws. That’s what makes them relatable and human (even if they’re an orc). Character Flaws earn you additional CrP, which is great. Flaws can also be used in social situations to further the story.

For a list of Flaws flip to Chapter 5: Flaws.

If you’ve gone into CrP debt and you’re not out of it by the end of this stage, you’ll need to go back and reselect your Archetypes so that you are or go back to you starting set of stats and begin Character Creation all over again with them.

7. ADJUST STATS

Now, it is time to do the final adjustments to your stats. While not your final adjustments: you'll have a chance to increase them again level up.

The price to increase a Stat is the Stat + 10. So, to get a Stat to 9 from 8, it would cost 18 CrP.

8. CALCULATE CHARACTER VITALS

Now it’s time to calculate your character’s Honor and Vitality.

These 2 things, along with Stress are important parts of the game and serve as the prime mechanics when running a Bonfire game. If you’re not familiar with them head over to Chapter 6: Character Vitals.

This chapter will also give you an overview of the character sheet that you’ll get more acquainted with later.

If you’ve already played Bonfire before, here’s a cheat sheet for calculating those things:

  • Honor: This is determined by your “Starting Honor” listed under your Charisma
  • Vitality: This is Con score + Primary Archetype’s Vitality Die + Vitality Size Modifier from race, divided into 4 Categories.

Don't forget that you get a bonus to your CrP from the Honor of your last character. If this is your first character, you instead get 25 CrP. Enjoy.

9. MASTERIES & SKILLS

Masteries and Skills are additional areas of expertise that your character has obtained above his or her race and class.

All three cost CrP. Prices and descriptions can be found in Chapter 8: Skills.

Out of Order Character Creation

If you’re a little bit more familiar with Bonfire Character creation, these last steps (step 9, 10, and 11) can be taken in any order you’d like, even skipping back and forth between them.

10. DEFINE SOCIAL CHARACTERISTICS

Your character is more than just raw stats, skills, and abilities. At this step, you’re going to define more about who they see themselves as and how others perceive them by defining their Traits, Passions, Goals, and Devotions. Jump to Chapter 9: Social.

11. BUY EQUIPMENT

Every character starts with a kit of gear, which has a list of per purchased starting gear as well as an extra bit of starting cash they you can spend on additional things. Proceed to Chapter 11: Equipment for a full list of available kits and gear you can pick up.

You may also cash in any left over CrP for sp at 1 CrP for 10 sc, but you don’t have to. You can save your CrP to spend later at your level up.

After purchasing your equipment, adjust your Encumbrance. Don’t forget that armor and shields will also modify this.

12. TRANSFER TO CHARACTER SHEET

Congratulations: you’re on the home stretch! Finish your character off by transferring your notes to a fresh character sheet, an example of which, with a break down, is found in Chapter 6: Character Vitals. You can also find a download for the character sheet here.

Exploding Dice

You’ll notice a exclamation mark (!) behind a lot of dice notations. This marks the dice as exploding, which means that should the maximum of that dice is rolled, you get to roll it again, this time with a - 1, and add what you rolled to the total.

This continues for as long as you roll the maximum dice, however, the - 1 always stays a -1 one.

So, if you roll a 3d8! for damage, you get a 5, 8, 8. Since you rolled the maximum value on two of your dice, you roll those dice again, and roll an 8, and 5, giving you a subtotal of 32 ( 5 + 8 + 8 + 8 - 1 + 5 - 1 ) but since you rolled another 8, you get to roll that dice again, and you get a 1, netting you a 0 ( 1 - 1 ).

There are two things you should be aware of: 1d100! explode to a 1d20!, while 1d20! explode to a d6!.

The second thing is that explosion dice don’t add additional dice to the number. So, in the example above, all that damage is only counted as having been done with 3 dice (instead of the 5 that were actually rolled).

Dice Size Hierarchy

Bonfire plays around a lot with dice sizes, so it’s important to know what dice to grab in those cases.

Dice sizes go as follows:

d2 → d3 → d4 → d6 → d8 → d10 → d12 → d20

If a d4 is exploding and drops to a d3 or lower, it stops exploding.

If the dice size increases past a d20, you’ll add an extra dice starting at a d4. Further dice sizes will increase this smaller dice. This can continue ad nauseum, but no matter how many dice there are, they’re always considered to be rolled on 1 dice.

So, 3d20! + d10! is still considered 1 dice.
Stat Scores

Stat Scores represent different dimensions of your character and how good their baseline is at certain activities. These dimensions are Strength, Dexterity, Constitution, Intellect, Wisdom, Charisma.

STAT CHECKS

There many come a time where a Skill Check doesn’t exactly cover what needs to be tested. What skill covers trying to deadlift a boulder or remember a fact about a person? When skills fail and it’s simply a raw test of an ability, Stat Checks come into play.

Players making an unopposed ability check roll a d20 and try to get a result equal to or under their their stat score. If the check is made at 1/2 the score, they're trying to roll equal to or under their score, rounded down. Should they do so, they succeed.

OPPOSED CHECKS

Opposed checks work almost the same. The player rolls a d20! + their relevant stat score vs an opposing d20! + any relevant modifiers (such as the boulder being really heavy or only their foes relevant stat score). The person with the higher total succeeds.

STRENGTH

Strength (Str) represents your character’s pure brawn. How much can she lift and carry? How strong are her punches?

DAMAGE

This number is added to your damage whenever your character hits something with their fits or uses thrown ranged weapons. It’s the raw, physical force he can put into an object.

CARRY

This number represents the number of items a character can carry in their hands before he gets more Encumbered. More on Encumbrance is found in Chapter 11: Equipment.

SKILL

This number represents the discount you apply to Skill costs whenever you buy a Skill with this as a listed Stat.

SOCIAL DIE

Sometimes your character’s strength can play into social situations, such as trying to intimidate your opponent. This is the die that gets added to your dice pool for Social Conflicts if your Strength is applicable.

DEXTERITY

Strength
Score Damage Carry Skill Social
1 -4 1S 0 n/a
2 -3 2S 0 n/a
3 -3 1M 0 n/a
4 -3 1M 1S 0 n/a
5 -2 1M 2S 0 n/a

8 -1 2M 2S 0 n/a
9 -1 1L 1 n/a
10 0 1L 1 n/a
11 1 1L 1 n/a
12 1 1L 1S 1 D4!
13 1 1L 2S 1 D4!

15 2 1L 1M 1S 2 D6!

19 3 1L 2M 2S 3 D12!
20 4 2L 3 D20!

5 -2 -2 1 0 n/a

12 1 1 0 1 D4!
13 1 1 0 1 D4!
14 1 1 0 2 D6!
15 2 2 0 2 D6!
16 2 2 -1 2 D8!
17 2 2 -1 2 D8!
18 2 2 -1 2 D10!
19 2 3 -2 3 D12!
20 3 3 -3 3 D20!

Dexterity (Dex) is a measure of how agile your character is. Can she dodge arrows or can she execute a graceful pirouette? Dexterity is crucial for avoiding blows in combat or traps in a hallway.

ATTACK

Being graceful allows your character to take advantage of openings others can’t. This number gets added to all attack rolls your character makes.

DEFENCE

If you can move quicker than your opponent, you can often get out of harm’s way before it becomes a problem. This number gets added to all melee defense rolls your character makes.

INITIATIVE

Another bonus of being quick on your feet is the ability to get moving quicker when manure hits the windmill. This number gets added to your initiative rolls at the beginning of combat.

SKILL

This number represents the discount you apply to Skill costs whenever you buy a Skill with this as a listed Stat.

SOCIAL DIE

Sometimes your character’s dexterity can play into social situations, such as trying to seduce your opponent. This is the die that gets added to your dice pool for Social Conflicts if your Dexterity is applicable.

CONSTITUTION

Constitution
Score Min Vitality Encumb. Skill Social
1 1 10 0 n/a
2 1 9 0 n/a
3 1 8 0 n/a
4 1 7 0 n/a
5 1 6 0 n/a
6 2 6 0 n/a
7 2 6 0 n/a
8 2 5 0 n/a
9 2 5 1 n/a
10 3 5 1 n/a
11 3 4 1 n/a
12 4 4 1 D4!
13 5 4 1 D4!
14 6 4 2 D6!
15 7 3 2 D6!
16 8 3 2 D8!
17 9 2 2 D8!
18 10 2 2 D10!
19 11 1 3 D12!
20 12 1 3 D20!

Constitution (Con) represents your character’s over all health and toughness. Can he shrug off the Dancing Death or does he succumb to a head cold? Can she take a solid blow in combat and not even blink? These are the things Constitution oversees.

Constitution is the base of your starting Vitality so don’t neglect it.

MIN VITALITY

Every other level, a character gains a reroll of their Vitality Die. This number is the minimum amount that reroll can be.

So, if a Fighter with 15 Constitution gets a 3 on their reroll, they add 4 to that result to get it to 7. This cannot exceed the amount that can be rolled on your dice. If a wizard has a minimum reroll of 7, they will still only get 4 Vitality from their dice.

ENCUMB.

Encumbrance plays a critical role in any fight and represents your character’s ability to mentally and physically overcome his weariness and struggle on.

More on calculating Encumbrance is found in Chapter 6: Character Vitals.

SKILL

This number represents the discount you apply to Skill costs whenever you buy a Skill with this as a listed Stat.

SOCIAL DIE

Sometimes your character’s constitution can play into social situations, such as convincing your opponent she really doesn’t want to fight you. This is the die that gets added to your dice pool for Social Conflicts if your Constitution is applicable.

INTELLECT

Intellect
Score Attack Lvl Crp Passion Skill Social
1 -4 15 0 0 n/a
2 -3 16 0 0 n/a
3 -3 17 0 0 n/a
4 -3 18 0 0 n/a
5 -2 18 0 0 n/a
6 -2 19 0 0 n/a
7 -1 19 0 0 n/a
8 -1 20 12 0 n/a
9 -1 20 12 1 n/a
10 0 20 12 1 n/a
11 1 20 12 1 n/a
12 1 20 12 1 D4!
13 1 21 16 1 D4!
14 2 21 20 2 D6!
15 2 22 24 2 D6!
16 2 22 28 2 D8!
17 3 23 32 2 D8!
18 3 23 36 2 D10!
19 3 24 40 3 D12!
20 4 25 44 3 D20!

Intellect (Int) measures your character’s raw knowledge: how much data can he remember? Can she do mathematical calculations or remember who the Elector of Stanitz is? Intellect doesn’t help in applying that knowledge but it does give you knowledge to draw on.

ATTACK

Being able to pinpoint holes in your opponent’s defense allows you to see openings that others don’t. A cunning intellect can help land a telling blow. This number is added to all attack rolls your character makes.

LvL CrP

A character with a high Intellect is able to grasp concepts and skills quicker than others, allowing him to learn more things than others in an equivalent amount of time. This is the amount of CrP that a character gets when they level up. More on leveling is found in Chapter 14: Character Progression.

PASSION POINTS

A true renaissance man has his fingers in many pies and this allows him to persuade and entice others. These points are spent to increase the strength of your character’s Passions.

SKILL

This number represents the discount you apply to Skill costs whenever you buy a Skill with this as a listed Stat.

SOCIAL DIE

Sometimes your character’s intelligence can play into social situations, such as convincing someone that you’re right simply because you know more. This is the die that gets added to your dice pool for Social Conflicts if your Intellect is applicable.

Roll to Recall

Details are hard to remember and notes can get lost or disorganized. To keep play moving, the player can make a Int Ability Check vs d20! to remember a piece of information that was heard in a previous session, such a person’s name or where someone came from.

To clarify: this can’t be used to remember information that was given to you this same session.

WISDOM

Wisdom
Score Defence Encumb. Init Skill Social
1 -4 7 5 0 n/a
2 -3 7 4 0 n/a
3 -3 7 3 0 n/a
4 -3 7 3 0 n/a
5 -2 6 2 0 n/a
6 -2 6 2 0 n/a
7 -1 6 1 0 n/a
8 -1 6 1 0 n/a
9 -1 6 1 1 n/a
10 0 5 0 1 n/a
11 1 5 0 1 n/a
12 1 5 0 1 D4!
13 1 5 0 1 D4!
14 2 5 0 2 D6!
15 2 4 -1 2 D6!
16 2 4 -1 2 D8!
17 3 4 -2 2 D8!
18 3 4 -2 2 D10!
19 3 3 -3 3 D12!
20 4 3 -4 3 D20!

Wisdom (Wis) is applied knowledge. Does she process information quicker and learn from other’s mistakes? Does he understand life is more than just a set of numbers of probabilities? Can she see other’s viewpoints? Wisdom can also be defined as force of will, the ability to overcome physical problems with mental force.

DEFENSE

Having greater body awareness allows you to keep your form tight and your limbs out of danger and where they need to be. This coupled with the ability to read your opponent allows the wise character to keep from getting hit. This number gets added to all melee defense rolls your character makes.

ENCUMB.

The ability to disconnect your mind from the pain and ignore your screaming muscles is part of what gives long distance runners their ability to run miles without tiring. Your ability to put yourself “in the zone” is represented by this number.

More on calculating Encumbrance is found in Chapter 6: Character Vitals.

INITIATIVE

Being able to process any situation quicker is important to staying alive. This number gets added to your initiative rolls at the beginning of combats so lower is better

SKILL

This number represents the discount you apply to Skill costs whenever you buy a Skill with this as a listed Stat.

SOCIAL DIE

Sometimes your character’s wisdom can play into social situations, such knowing exactly what to say to a grieving friend. This is the die that gets added to your dice pool for Social Conflicts if your Wisdom is applicable.

CHARISMA

Charisma
Score Favor Start Honor Min Honor Trait Followers Skill Social
1 1 Dishonor 0 0 0 0 n/a
2 1 Low 0 0 0 0 n/a
3 1 Low 0 0 0 0 n/a
4 1 Low 0 0 0 0 n/a
5 1 Average 0 0 0 0 n/a
6 1 Average 0 14 1 0 n/a
7 2 Average 0 14 1 0 n/a
8 2 Average 0 32 2 0 n/a
9 2 Average 0 32 2 1 n/a
10 2 Average 0 42 4 1 n/a
11 3 Average 0 42 5 1 n/a
12 3 Average 1 52 6 1 D4!
13 4 Average 1 62 7 1 D4!
14 4 Average 2 72 8 2 D6!
15 5 Average 2 78 9 2 D6!
16 6 Average 3 84 10 2 D8!
17 7 High 3 97 11 2 D10!
18 8 High 4 110 12 2 D12!
19 8 High 5 117 14 3 D20!
20 9 Great 6 124 16 3 D20!+d4!

Charisma (Cha) represents force of personality. Does he bend others to his will? Is she the focus of any room she enters? Do people look up to them or what to be him? Charisma is not looks or even likeability: it represents this animal magnatism that people follow.

FAVOR

The gods are fickle creatures, bestowing their gifts on some and their ire on others, and often switch with the seasons, however, charismatic characters tend to do well for themselves.

This is the minimum amount of Favor a person gets whenever they roll their Devotion die to gain Favor. If this minimum is greater than the die size, you receive the max of that dice instead. More information about that is found in Chapter 13: The Divine.

START HONOR

Being well thought of allows your character to hold his head high in any situation, giving him the edge. This is your character’s starting Honor category. You can find out more in Chapter 6: Character Vitals.

MIN HON

Charismatic people may find themselves on the wrong end of opinion but they often don’t find themselves there for long. At the end of each session, if your character’s Honor is under this threshold, they jump up to this much Honor. You can find out more in Chapter 6: Character Vitals.

FOLLOWERS

This is the total number of Followers your character has to draw on during his adventuring career. More on Followers is found in Appendix 1: GM's Guide.

TRAIT POINTS

Characters with strong personalities tend to have a lot of definable qualities that allow them to blend into any social group or a few really strong ones that people seem drawn to. These points are spent increase the number and/or strength of your character’s Traits.

SKILL

This number represents the discount you apply to Skill costs whenever you buy a Skill with this as a listed Stat.

SOCIAL DIE

Sometimes your character’s charisma can play into social situations, such seducing someone. This is the die that gets added to your dice pool for Social Conflicts if your Charisma is applicable.

Races

A BRIEF OVERVIEW OF THE HISTORY OF THE MIDDLE REALM

In the beginning, the Divines created the Painted World, in which they placed their first children. The Painted World was mutable and the source of all magic and there the First Children lived happily, beautiful, skilled, and perfect in everyway.

They were the delight of all the Divines, save one: the trickster Divine, Rostam. Rostam quickly grew bored of the First Children and the constant fawning they received from the Divines.

And so, under the guise of creating servants for the Divines, he created the Dwarves. He made the opposite of the First Children - crude, mean, ugly, and incorrigible in the extreme. They caused such an uproar in the Higher Realm that the Divines banished them to the Nothing beyond the Gate of Heaven, where certain death awaited them in the embrace of non-existent nothing.

The Father of the Dwarves took his people and before passing through the Gate of Heaven, slew the giant Ymir, who stood guard there and tossed his body into the Nothing. The All-Father and his sons jumped from the Gate and onto Ymir and from his bones they made the Middle Realm; the giant’s blood, the oceans and his muscles, the earth.

There they lived a profane life, in defiance of the Divines. With the protection of the Bones of Ymir, the dwarves were able to avoid the direct displeasure of the Divines and so the Divines needed to think of different ways to reach them in their holds.

They created the Bonfire, links to the Higher Realm, through which they sent the unthinking evils of the world through but the dwarves repulsed them.

And so they created their Second Children, avenging angels robed in flesh, to travel through the Bonfires and war with the dwarves.

But after centuries of war, the Second Children changed: they became obsessed with the total destruction of the dwarves and so they chained themselves to the Bonfires, harnessing the Divine against its wills. They became the orcs.

Appalled at what their Children had become, the Divines sent their First Children to bring the orcs back into the fold, but the orcs rebelled, sacrificing some of the First Children on the Bonfires and thus was born the human race.

Centuries have passed and the Middle Realm changes those that walk there. The First Children eventually called it home and became the elves.

WHICH RACE SHOULD I CHOOSE?

Your race effects character creation in 3 ways: Stat Score Modifiers, Gameplay Rewards, and Archetype Costs. If you're new to RPGs in generally, go for a race that interests you based on the flavor.

STAT SCORE MODIFIERS

These modify the base stats that you roll. You can use it to balance out your character's weak spots or you can use it to maximize what your character is already good it. We recommend the latter as Bonfire is a game built around teamwork: you'll have friends who will be good at things your character isn't.

GAMEPLAY REWARDS

Each race is meant to encourage a certain type of play. For instance, orcs gain bonuses for starting things, like combats or social conflicts, so they reward players who are aggressive, while elves get rewarded for being careful with how they engage with others. These are noted under the Racial Temperament section in their summary.

ARCHETYPE COSTS

Some races can spend less time mastering things than others, freeing up time (CrP) to focus on other pursuits or becoming true masters of their vocation. This is reflected in the Archetype Costs.

You'll notice that some races will have Archetype Exceptions: these are based on the lore of that race for the Middle Realm, the official campaign setting of Bonfire. GMs should feel free to modify these prices. Actually, GMs should modify any prices to fit their setting.

RACIAL PREFERENCES

🜂 Advanced Rule

Racial tensions exist in the Middle Realm and there’s bad blood between the different species, plus, some races get on other's nerves because of differing temperaments. When in a Conflict against some races, you can sometimes gain Leverage to resist (or they get Leverage to convince you).

Racial Preferences
Races Being Judged
Races Judging
Dwarf Changeling Elf Gaunt Minotaur Human Orc Ratfolk
Dwarf Preferred Like Tolerate Tolerate Tolerate Tolerate Tolerate Preferred
Changeling Like Preferred Like Dislike Hate Preferred Dislike Preferred
Elf Dislike Like Preferred Dislike Like Tolerate Hate Preferred
Gaunt Dislike Like Like Tolerate Tolerate Tolerate Tolerate Preferred
Minotaur Tolerate Dislike Dislike Dislike Preferred Like Dislike Preferred
Human Like Tolerate Like Dislike Like Preferred Dislike Preferred
Orc Hate Tolerate Dislike Like Dislike Tolerate Dislike Preferred
Ratfolk Preferred Like Like Preferred Preferred Preferred Preferred Preferred

Preferred: 2d6! Leverage when trying to convince

Like: d6! Leverage when trying to convince

Tolerate: No Leverage

Dislike: d6! Leverage when trying to resist

Hate: 2d6! Leverage when trying to resist

So, an elf is trying to convince an orc to do something. Orcs dislike elves as a whole: they're efete and cowardly and can be extremely passive-aggressive to an orc, so immediately they start off on the wrong foot, giving the orc a d6! to resist the elf's coercion. The elf, realizing that this is going to be harder than it needs to be because of the orcs bullheadedness and general lack of forethought, goes to the his human friend and tries to get him to sign on. Because humans like elves, the elf would get a d6! to convince him instead.

Orcs treat their own kin as Preferred for Racial Preferences.

CHANGELINGS

🜂 Advanced Rule

Changeling Summary

MODIFIERS

-4 Str

+2 Dex

+3 Wis

Small Sized (- 1 ft to Measure, +3 to Melee & Ranged Defense, less movement, and require less food)

Vitality Size Modifier is 10

RACIAL TEMPERAMENT

Crafty

ARCHETYPE COSTS

Expert: 10

Servant: 20

Caster: 15

Socialite: 15

Fighter: 25

Changelings are strange little beings. The rumors are that their demons who've trade places with human children left out in the wild or that they're the stillborn children of wizards and witches. Either way, their wiliness and techincal prowess make them welcome guests where every they end up.

HISTORY

Changelings were said to first appear in the employ of hedge wizards and witches in the hinterlands of the Rhon mountains. They were usually attached to a village, where they worked as tinkers and menders, or as helpers in workshops.

During the spread of the First Empire, many officials specifically went out and drafted them, recruiting them as armours, sappers, or magic-users in the army or household artists, as they had a keen artistic eye and creative spirit. They formed their own communities and many bought their freedom, seeking their own way in the world but many stayed as it was a good gig.

As the First Empire fell, many changelings simply integrated into the local culture. Those that didn't often found themselves the target of persecution, accused of being traitors to the Empire or simply scapegoated for their unwillingness to give up their culture.

With the rise of the Second Empire, they have, however, once again found a safe place in the machinary of state, but many still long for the quiet life in a tucked away community where they can tinker and mend away.

APPEARANCE

Changelings are about the size of a 10 year old human, with extremely pale skin, unsually long fingers and large eyes. Besides this, they appear like little humans, with whispy hair on their head and face.

They dress in whatever the area custom is but tend towards bright and clashing colors.

PERSONALITY

Changelings are wily and crafty, and, while not lacking in morality, tend to get caught up on whatever project they're currently on. They enjoy puzzles more than anything - the thrill of having everything click into place just perfectly is the finest thing a person can experiance.

They also tend to be on the shy side, as much as possible, keeping out of the limelight. Worldly power and accolades hold little appeal for them, but there is a sense of wanting to be apart something greater than keeps them reaching out to the outside world.

DWARVES

🜂 Advanced Rule

Dwarf Summary

MODIFIERS

-3 Dex

+4 Con

-2 Cha

Small Sized (- 1 ft to Measure, +3 to Melee & Ranged Defense, less movement, and require less food)

Vitality Size Modifier is 20

RACIAL TEMPERAMENT

Unconquerable

ARCHETYPE COSTS

Expert: 15

Servant: 35

Caster: n/a

Socialite: 25

Fighter: 10

Archetype Exceptions

Paragon Acolyte: 20

Symbolist: 20

Dwarves are called the 'Stonemen' not because they're made of stone but because they're hard as rock. They're obstinate and incorrigible and, as a rule, they never do anything that someone else wants them to do. As such, they're the most disagreeable beings in the Middle Realm. They're also the most straightforward, brave, and loyal beings as well.

HISTORY

Dwarves were made by the Divine Rostam for one purpose: to try and get the other Divines to stop huffing their own farts and realize their not infalible. As such, he took their favorite children, those beings that would become the elves, and flipped them on their head.

Needless to say, when these little buggers became running around the Higher World, the other Divines were not amused and quickly tried to get rid of them by banishing them to the Void.

Well, the dwarves were not going to be beaten so easily. After all, any one could be sentenced to non-existance by being throwing into the endless Nothing. So, they slew the guardian, Ymir, and threw his body into the Nothing and thus created the Middle Realm.

The rest of dwarven history is filled with the Divine's futile attempts to scrub them from the world but finally as the gods began to relax and realize how much they overracted, the Dwarves soon found themselves fighting amongst themselves.

Currently, they've ditched their isolation policy and have begun to interact with the outside world.

APPEARANCE

Dwarves are the opposite of elves. They're short, barrel chested with thick hair growing all over their bodies. This hair ranges from coal black to a golden hue, depending on which hold the dwarf hails from. They also always support big bushy beards that are near hard as steel.

These beards are their pride and joy and they take great care in them. Woven into each beard is the tale of that dwarf's life and accomplishments as well as their job within the hold. You can learn a lot from reading a dwarf's beard.

Besides this and their tools, the dwarves really don't take care of themselves, eschewing anything showy or fancy, like nice fabrics or baths.

Dwarf anatomy is, thankfully, a mystery to most outsiders. All dwarves, to other races, appear human and use human pronouns, though in dwarvish, their are no pronouns because that's more bothersome. There is a rumor that their are female dwarves but that there's 0 sexual dimorphism in the species, which makes courting a very careful affair, but the running theory is that female dwarves are just anvils.

PERSONALITY

As stated before, dwarves are subborn. They're very rarely, however, psychopathically so. More often, once they have decided something, they tend to get defencive and refuse to relent unless they absolutely have to.

This makes dwarven governments and social structures very slow moving and difficult to work with but, it also means that if you get a dwarf to agree with you, they will happily die on that hill.

In fact, the only time that a dwarf seems to be happy is when he's being stubborn about something.

Finally, dwarves do not ascribe to social niceties. It's not that they're incapabile to understanding them or aware of them: they just don't think they're worth paying attention to, in the same way that most people don't notice insects.

ELVES

Elf Summary

MODIFIERS

-2 Str

-4 Con

+4 Int

+2 Cha

Medium Sized

Vitality Size Modifier is 10

RACIAL TEMPERAMENT

Patient

ARCHETYPE COSTS

Expert: 15

Servant: 15

Caster: 10

Socialite: 10

Fighter: 20

The Elves are the first born of the Divines. Originally, the inhabitants of the Painted World, the source of all magic, they now inhabit the Middle Realm as mentally ethereal beings.

HISTORY

After the corruption of the Orcs, the Divines sought another means of assailing the Dwarves in their holds. They turned to the First Children, the Elves.

So, they marshaled the elven forces and invaded the Middle Realm.

The invasion proved more fruitful than the first one. The Elves’ ethereal nature allowed them to interact with the Middle Realm without being corrupted by it and their corporeal bodies allowed them to wage war on the Dwarves on their own terms.

But there were side effects of their new environment. The Elves, who used to be nearest to the Divines, found that they were now less connected to their creators. With all that reality in the way, their prayers had a harder time of reaching the Divines.

After generations, the Elves have become dispersed, their common cause mostly forgotten and their heritage lost to the mists of time. Some continue the war, but most of them have integrated into the societies of the Middle Realm as artisans, scholars, and wizards.

APPEARANCE

Elves are slender beings that are widely considered classically beautiful, though many find their features alien and off putting. They uniformly have long ears that taper to a point at the end.

Their eyes are pure white, with no iris or pupil visible, this matched with their sharp teeth, can give them a feline turn to their face.

Elves naturally survive off the ebb and flow of magic that drifts through the air of the Painted World. While still present in the Middle Realm, these winds are a sliver of their natural magnitude and so Elves need to find other sources; the main one being through the magic inherent in all living creatures. While vegetables do have magic in them, an Elf would have to consume 100s of pounds of lettuce each day to not die of starvation. The only realistic way of getting enough magic to survive is through the consumption of raw meat.

PERSONALITY

To describe an Elf as “careful” would be a huge understatement. They tend to live longer than other races, not because some supernaturally long lifespan, but because they're always careful about their actions. They see other races as brash and impetuous while they're in turn seen as slow and cowardly.

It's not they're incapable of great emotion or quick action but elves seem to understand that with every action comes a consquence, whether that action was well meaning or not, and that this karmic force is more powerful than any other law or power.

However, once set on a course, it is hard to dissaude an elf, for they do nothing lightly.

GAUNTS

🜂 Advanced Rule

Gaunt Summary

MODIFIERS

-2 Str

+2 Dex

-3 Con

-3 Int

+2 Wis

+3 Cha

Medium Sized

Vitality Size Modifier is 10

RACIAL TEMPERAMENT

Salvation Secured

ARCHETYPE COSTS

Expert: 10

Servant: 35

Caster: 10

Socialite: 10

Fighter: 10

Gaunts are said to be depraved creatures stuck between life and death. They love filthy lucre more than what made them human. They're those that, for whatever reason, have sold part of their souls for either money or at a change at eternal life in the world to come.

HISTORY

During the last days of the Old Vyatichi Kingdom, those with the power sought a way to cheat death and become immortal. While they didn't find the cure, they found a bandage: soul shiving, the process of grafting a piece of another's soul onto one's own to prolong your life. The priests and shamans talked about the gift they would give those who did this: how a piece of their soul would travel with them to heaven after death, granting even the vilest sinner reprieve. They also offered a hefty pay bonus too.

And thus the first gaunts were born as the husks of those that sought a shortcut to salvation. Once the Empire took over, they outlawed the practices but it couldn't be undone, not the ritual or the knowledge and certain government officials also partook until it was an open secret. Many became man servants or thralls to these officials, pulled by some invisible thread together.

Crack downs by the Orthodoxy, both on practioners and gaunts themselves took place, with many going into hiding while others were rounded up into ghettoes. Many were burned at the stake during the last years of the Empire.

Not that the gaunts seemed to care. With salvation in the next world secured, most lived riot, indulging in the most depraved and headless way possible. Forming gangs and joining outcasts, becoming actors, and living life as if every day was their last. This, along with the church's indictment, only further estranged them from society.

And so on the edges of those societies they live, for the most part. Joining acting troopes or sellsword companies and generally making their way in the world where they can find a place to live out their final mortal days.

APPEARANCE

Gaunts of all races look generally the same as the soul shiving process drains them of their vitality. Their skin turns ghost white, their hair a weak grey, and their eyes become milky as if they're blind. Their bodies becoming desiccated, thin and reedy.

They still need to eat, drink, and do other bodily functions - they are, even after all that, living.

Gaunts tend to dress in flamboyent clothing that is a mix and match of whatever they kind find. Most say this is because they loot the clothing off of those they kill but it's more likely because they just wear what they can find or because they wish to make up for their dull color palette

PERSONALITY

As stated, gaunts get a bad rep for being wholely without morals but that's not always the case. Some have undergone the process because they need to feed thier families or out of a powerful sense of devotion or religious zeal so actually gaunts run the spectrum of personality types: they're just saddled with their reputation because of an admittedly not small section of them.

What makes up the gaunt's personality is why he made the sacrifice to do what he did. Why was so precious to him that he would make such a huge sacrifice for? That's a complicated question and not easy to answer by the gaunt player should have their answer before play begins.

HUMANS

Human Summary

MODIFIERS

Medium Sized

Vitality Size Modifier is 15

RACIAL TEMPERAMENT

We all have our theories on what personality traits that are shared by the human race and I'm not interested in wading in on that debate so instead of having a Racial Temperament, Humans increase their Honor Dice by 1 size.

ARCHETYPE COSTS

Expert: 10

Servant: 10

Caster: 10

Socialite: 10

Fighter: 10

Humans are the first natives of the Middle Realm. They are creatures born from strife, who’ve carved for themselves a place in the world through fire, steel, and grit.

HISTORY

The first Humans were born from the embers and ash of the Bonfires during the Elf-Orc Wars. Orc warlords discovered they could strengthen and corrupt the Bonfires by burning Elves alive in the its flame.

But out of the remains rose new life: a creature of both heaven and earth.

These children of the Middle Realm survived by forming clans in the hills and mountains, away from the fighting, and there they began to thrive.

The turning point in their civilization was when the Divines discovered their unique connection with the Humans. Each Human carried a Bonfire inside them, making them perfect vessels for the favor of the gods. The Divines began focusing their attention on them and bestowing their gifts on their adopted children.

Humans have now become the preeminent race in the Middle Realm, with kingdoms and empires across the world.

APPEARANCE

The Humans of the Middle Realm look like you and me. Their skin, eye, and hair color range widely, adapted to the region of that Human’s origin, with darker skins more common towards the equator.

If you don’t know what a Human looks like, I don’t know what to tell you.

PERSONALITY

The truth is Humans are odd and quirky individuals that seem to have the defining trait of their curiosity and ambition.

Truthfully, you probably have your own opinion about how humans behave and why they behave the way they do and nothing I write in this little blurb is going to convince you otherwise.

MINOTAURS

🜂 Advanced Rule

Minotaur Summary

MODIFIERS

+4 Str

-5 Dex

+5 Con

-3 Int

-4 Cha

Large Sized (+ 1 ft to Measure, -3 to Melee & Ranged Defense, more movement, and require more food)

Vitality Size Modifier is 20

RACIAL TEMPERAMENT

Proud

ARCHETYPE COSTS

Expert: 20

Servant: 15

Caster: 30

Socialite: 25

Fighter: 10

Archetype Exceptions

Priest: 10: Shaman: 35

Paragon Acolyte: 10

Beastmen are uncivilizated creatures of an untamed nature but not Minotaurs. Through the Bonfire they've formed a New Covenant with the Divines, remaking their minds in their image. They were the founders of the First Empire and their legacy is still cleaved to by the kings of the age.

HISTORY

The rise of the minotaurs trace their origin back to the Sack of Um Badr, an event that, at the time only mattered to the Beja, but would have world changing consquences. Details are sketchy since beastmen are barbaric and don't keep records but the story goes that using the Bonfire in the city, the minotaurs were able to forge a New Covenant with the Divines, granting them almost human intelligence.

From there, the minotaurs organized themselves together and swept through the Rhon, subjegating the tribes there, overrunning the dwarven hold and learning all that they could. And like that, the First Empire was born.

Like an unstoppable tide, it conquered most of the known world - bringing all under one banner. And so there was an age of peace undreamed off.

But it wouldn't last: minotaurs, while inspired warriors and generals, have no real strong talent for statecraft. Religious revivials, both at home and abroad caused cultural and population shifts that destablized the government. Rich merchants were soon flexing their power over officials, with wanton corruption investing all levels. It was all too much and the Empire cracked and fell apart.

Now there are minotaur kingdoms dotted the land, powerful but small states, but most make there way in other's lands. Still, there legacy lives on with their symbols still used by burgeoning states, event those founded by their traditional enemies.

But, alas, the new Empire that now conqueres only pays lip service to them and is founded by humans who seek to be associated with bygone ages.

APPEARANCE

Minotaurs are huge creatures that are half man and half bull. Specifically, the head and upper torse, as well as the legs are bull, while the chest, shoulders, and arms are those of a man.

Both male and female are larger than the average person, with males standing on average about 7 ft tall and the woman standing at around 6 ft tall. Males sprout horns, though they lack the strength to effectively gore with them like their bull counterparts.

Their skin color, as well as their fur color and pattern, vary by region, with traditionall tanner skinned minotaurs coming from the south and light skinned ones coming from the north but during the days of the First Empire there was so much population movement that this is a trend rather than a rule.

Note that Minotaurs are more closely related to Beastfolk than they are to cows and so are, in fact, carnivorous.

PERSONALITY

Minotaurs cut royal figures and their personalities match. They have an extreme sense of pride and a great depth of feeling in accordance with their beastial nature.

They're extremely devoted to whatever cause they throw their weight behind and there is no difference to them between their opinions and themselves, making them very cocksure. This can, unsurprisingly, make them bullies as they care little for other's opinions about things.

ORCS

Orc Summary

MODIFIERS

+4 Str

+3 Con

-4 Int

-4 Cha

Medium Sized

Vitality Size Modifier is 15

RACIAL TEMPERAMENT

Aggressive

ARCHETYPE COSTS

Expert: 20

Servant: 25

Caster: 20

Socialite: 30

Fighter: 10

Archetype Exceptions

Priest: n/a: Shaman: 20

Avenging angels who know how to make war like others know how to breathe. The Orcs have been corrupted by the Middle Realm, now forging their destiny with their own hands.

HISTORY

Confounded by the Dwarves, who used the corpse of Ymir to form the Middle Realm and shield themselves from the power of the Divines, the Divines began to formulate an invasion to massacre the Stone Folk.

They crafted corporeal angels to wage war in the Middle Realm and they created the Bonfires as heavenly invasion points.

Centuries passed and the Orcs changed. Ages of violence transformed them and they became narrow minded in their pursuit of the total destruction of the dwarvish race.

It was discovered that Orcish warlords could link themselves to the Bonfires, wresting power from the Divines against their will, and so the gods turned their backs on their wayward children.

But the wars continued and the Orcs used the link to elevate their own ancestors to a faux deity state, replacing the Divines.

The Orcs, since blinded by war, have been crushed and dispersed, their descendants found as mercenaries and bandits across the Middle Realm, with a few Orcish Warlords still offering resistance from their ancient citadels.

APPEARANCE

Orcs have dark green or grey skin with porcine nose and tusks that jut up from their lower jaw. They tend to be stocky, with thick muscles and hunched shoulders.

Their hair is wiry, closer to steel wool than anything else and their eyes are completely black, with no pupils or irises, giving them an indescribable inhumanness to it.

Naturally, Orcs are scavengers, able to survive on practically anything, no matter how rotten or foul.

PERSONALITY

An Orc’s whole life revolves around conflict and they tend to view the world in that way. If it doesn’t allow them to get a leg up on their enemy, why bother with it?

The issue is that they don’t really have common sense: if it doesn’t directly relate to warfare, they don’t see the benefit.

So, weapons and armor, sure, but growing food? I don’t see how it gives me the leg up. Let others do it and I’ll just raid them for theirs.

Orcs aren’t that much dumber than the average person but their brains tend to overheat when thinking about complex topics.

RATFOLK

🜂 Advanced Rule

Ratfolk Summary

MODIFIERS

-6 Str

-4 Con

+3 Wis

+5 Cha

Small Sized (- 1 ft to Measure, +3 to Melee & Ranged Defense, less movement, and require less food)

Vitality Size Modifier is 10

RACIAL TEMPERAMENT

Helpful

ARCHETYPE COSTS

Expert: 10

Servant: 20

Caster: 15

Socialite: 15

Fighter: 25

Archetype Exceptions

Noble: 40

Ratfolk are social creatures. They love people and being around people. Others find them pleasant to be around. As such, Ratfolk can be found as diplomats, traders, and minstrals.

HISTORY

Ratfolk were the result of advanced Bejaian magics. After the Gothic and Capatian rebels, a spirit of fear riot in the city-states that a similar uprising might quickly come so the need for loyal servants inspired some of the greatest magic-users of the age to begin work on creating a race of people specifically made to be amenable. Thus, the first ratfolk.

Under the Empire, ratfolk came into high demand and those the Beja were secretive with their secrets, they were happy to swap them for coin and thus the creatures spread all over the continent, mainly as house servants.

They eventually became extremely well known for making excellent spies and were called in to defuse hostile situations, as if they radianted an innate calming aura.

But magic is wily and it soon became clear that the ratfolk were cunning, desiring more out of life than just to play second fiddle to others and so they sold their skills to the dwarven holds and enemies of the Empire to gain their freedom and a level of automony.

And so the last Primarch of the Empire fell by ratfolk hands, putting the last nail in the coffin.

APPEARANCE

Ratfolk are smaller and slimmer than other races, with lithe, fur covered bodies that range from auburn to dark black. They have beady eyes and long tails. For the most part, they appear like their smaller cousins, though with lighter frames and opposible thumbs.

PERSONALITY

As stated, ratfolk are people people. They're extremely social and, as a rule, are extroverted. They tend to be agreeable and try to get along with everyone but this shouldn't be taken as people pleasing or weak because ratfolk are clever - dangerously so.

People tend to think that because ratfolk are so easy going that they're push overs and that they can be taken advantage of but ratfolk sees it as "I'll scratch your back, you scratch mine" kind of deal so they're not just going to do things to do things. They very much believe in the social contract, but their animal nature makes them ruthless as some points.

In fact, ratfolk can be quite ruthless to those they deem outside their pack, which has earned them some reputation as having a herd mentality. For ratfolk the only war is total war.

Archetypes

Archetypes represent your character’s background training and starting skills. Your character’s class is a gestalt of two Archetypes of your choosing.

Archetypes are divided into Archetype Categories: Expert, Caster, Servant, Socialite, and Fighter. These represent the overall theme of the individual Archetype. For instance, Fighter Archetypes tend to be good at things related to combat. So, if you’re looking to make a combat focused character, you can look there.

You choose a Primary and a Secondary Archetype and pay the price in CrP for both based on your race.

You use the Vitality Die, the Skills & Masteries, and the Primary Drawback sections from the Primary, and combine both Archetype Abilities section, though you remove 1 leveling ability from your Secondary Archetype.

While you may want to double down into the exact same Archetype, Caster Archetypes are the only ones that you can do that with. You may choose two Archetypes from the same Category, however.

Your GM may choose to reject an Archetype combination based on the fact that the two Archetypes don’t fit together thematically. So, while a Thief/Priest (Beast Covenant) might be really powerful because of the Beast Covenant’s Shape Changing ability, if there’s not a Patron of Thieves and Animals in the campaign world, you’re out of luck.

If two characters have the same ability, unless it says otherwise, those abilities stack.

Expert Archetypes are those that focus on real-world non-combat skills, as opposed to relying on the Divines or magic as a source of strength.

Expert Archetypes tend to rely on Intellect and Wisdom, primarily.

ADVENTURER

Adventures gain the most free skills of all Archetypes allowing for the largest breathe of knowledge, however, they’re cheaper skills. They can also help others, giving them a chance to try again at Skill Checks they fail.

VITALITY DIE

d8

SKILLS & MASTERIES

Adventurers receive 2 free purchases of any two different, non-Lore Skill Suites.

ARCHETYPE ABILITIES

HELPING HAND The Adventurer is not just about knowing things but also giving others a helping hand in times of need. When another person uses an Adventurer’s help, either as an Asset, or one of his Helper Skills or Preparation, they receive an additional +1 to their roll. This bonus increases by +1 for every 2 levels the Adventurer has obtained.

MIDDLE NAME: DANGER For the Adventurer, danger is calming and straightforward and that’s what they crave. Whenever an Adventurer takes damage, they can heal that amount of Stress. This doesn’t heal Stress from wounds, however.

SKILL FOCUS (Any < 7 CrP, 6) At first level and every level up, Adventurers receive 6 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skills under 7 CrP in base cost (before Skill Adept and Stat Score reduction) within either of the two Skill Suites he picked at first level. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level but are applied after Skills have been bought by the Character.

SKILL ADEPT This character has a knack for skills. All Advanced Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all Skill Suites. This stacks with other Skill Adepts.

PRIMARY DRAWBACK

Adventurers tend to eschew book smarts for street smarts: the Lore Skill Suite and any Lore Advanced Skills cost double.

ASSASSIN

🜂 Advanced Rule

The Assassin is a master killer, gaining a chance to increase their damage against unaware opponents and being able silence helpless ones quickly. They're also masters of poison use, knowing how to most effectively apply their killer medicine.

VITALITY

d4

SKILLS & MASTERIES

Assassins receive 1 free purchase of the Streetwise Skill Suite.

ARCHETYPE ABILITIES

BACKSTAB When using any small melee weapon against an unaware target (one that is either not aware of your presence or one that is unaware that you, personally, mean harm to them), the Assassin’s damage explodes on the highest and second highest result. i.e., d4!s explode on natural 3s and 4s. They also gain an additional dice of damage every 2 levels when backstabbing, which doesn’t increase the total number of dice for /D armor.

If an opponent flees and the Assassin is within half their weapon Recovery, they may Backstab using half their additional damage dice from this ability.

IMPROVED COUP de GRACE An Assassin has studied the weak parts of their target’s anatomy and can quickly make a killer strike. Coup de Graces only take 5 seconds. This is always done completely silent.

COOL HEADED Where others would get blustered, the Assassin stays cool, even when he’s stressing. When making a Skill Check, lower the base amount of Stress you get by 2.

SKILLED POISONER An Assassin has intimate knowledge of poisons and how to use them. When someone is poisoned by the Assassin, increase that poison's Lethality by 1 for every level that Assassion has obtained.

PRIMARY DRAWBACK

Being a trained killer is not an honorable profession and people don’t like murders around. If your profession becomes publicly known, you lose 5 Honor.

MASTERMIND

🜂 Advanced Rule

The Mastermind is a plotter: preparing themselves and laying out plans before they step foot into the Skill Challenge. They get bonuses for utilizing all the options presented in the Strategies section, meaning that, by the time they step into the ring, they’re unbeatable in their element.

VITALITY DIE

d6

SKILLS & MASTERIES

Masterminds receive 1 free purchase of Skill Suite of their choice.

ARCHETYPE ABILITIES

FRIENDS in ALL PLACE A Mastermind has contacts and knows how to use them. When using an Asset, the Mastermind gains a +1 at first level and increases it by 1 for every level they’ve obtained.

METHODICALLY MINDED If you’re careful with how you treat your equipment and come prepared, you can see yourself through a tough spot. You may pay 15 Stress so that you or others who use your equipment ignore the degradation of a piece of equipment you use on a Check. This Stress penalty is lowered by 1 every 3 levels down to a minimum of 3.

PREP PAYS OFF People take pride in having their plans work out, the Mastermind doubly so. Whenever a reroll from Preparation results in a success when the original roll would have caused a failure, the Mastermind receives 1 free use of their Honor Die for the rest of the Skill Challenge.

The RIGHT TOOL for the RIGHT TIME If you’re careful with how you treat your equipment and come prepared, you can see yourself through a tough spot. Once per Skill Challenge and an additional time for every 2 levels they’ve obtained, ignore the degradation of a piece of equipment you use on a Check.

SKILL FOCUS (Any, 3) At first level and every level other up, Masterminds receive 3 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skill. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level but are applied after Skills have been bought by the Character.

SKILL ADEPT This character has a knack for skills. All Advanced Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all Skill Suites. This stacks with other Skill Adepts.

PRIMARY DRAWBACK

Failure means that the Mastermind didn’t plan as well as he should have. He gains an additional 2 Stress Dice at the end of any Skill Challenge for each Obstacle that he fails, even if he got what he wanted out of the Challenge.

OPPORTUNIST

🜂 Advanced Rule

There’s just something about these types of people that seem to warp probability in their favor. And those lucky few who use this to their advantage to go far.

VITALITY DIE

the higher of 2d6

SKILLS & MASTERIES

Opportunists gain the Skills & Masteries from their Secondary Archetype.

ARCHETYPE ABILITIES

LUCKY The Opportunist is naturally blessed with the ability to get out of trouble and use that adrenaline that comes as death comes near to dodge the grim reaper and keep running. After the results are given, the Opportunist can take 2 Stress to modify his results by 1. These may be done with the following conditions:

  • They can never be used to make you a better fighter. Stress gained this way can only be used to dodge death or escape a bad situation but never to make your character a superman.
  • The character must think of a situation that saves his rear end, something that happens to him that’s to his advantage.

The key here is that it can’t be impossible but it can be highly improbable. The chandelier rope breaking right at that moment separating him from a blood thirsty guard, a pigeon flying across an archer’s view intercepting an arrow, etc. are all acceptable.

It can’t be the result of skill. Him deflecting the blade with his hand like a badass is right out.

Should the character be unable to think of a scenario that fits both of these criteria, he’s unable to gain Stress to save himself.

FALL FORWARD Some people seem to stubble into where they need to be, even when they completely fail. When the Opportunist fails a Check, takes damage, or loses a round, he gains a roll of his Honor Dice. This is limited to 1 initially (so failing a second roll won't do him any good at level 1), but for every 3 levels the Opportunist has obtained, he increases the max number of Honor Dice this ability gives him by 1.

NATURAL ADVANTAGE A Opportunist lives on his wits and his ability to use every advantage. At the start of every Combat, Conflict, or Skill Challenge, he may change one thing about the field for every 10 Stress he takes. These changes must be consistent with an overarching setting (he can’t choose to have the inn change to a ship or flood right at that moment but he can choose to have a convenient chair or barrel right behind one of his enemies or reposition himself next to the fighter).

This Stress is lowered by 1 for every level he’s obtained, down to 3, though he may use this ability multiple times, but it doubles the Stress penalty each time he does so. This resets the next time he has the opportunity to heal Stress.

PRIMARY DRAWBACK

Luck is a top heavy thing: Opportunists don’t get their Vitality reroll every other level, however, they do get bumped up to their Min. Vitality from their Constitution if they’re below it.

PROFESSIONAL

🜂 Advanced Rule

While other Experts focus on knowledge, the Professional focuses on when to apply that knowledge and how to use their time effectively. The work with the Clocks of the Skill Challenge primarily, rather than being just good at Skill Checks.

VITALITY DIE

d6

SKILLS & MASTERIES

Professionals receive 1 free purchase of Skill Suite of their choice.

ARCHETYPE ABILITIES

UNDER PRESSURE When times get tough, the tough get going and the Professional is tough. The first time an Obstacle becomes Active, you gain an additional use of your Honor Die for the remainder of the Conflict. This increases by 1 Honor Die for every level you’ve obtained and only happens once for each Obstacle.

BUYING TIME The sands of the hourglass trickle onward but sometimes you can slow it down for a moment or two. During a Skill Challenge on a failed Check, you can sacrifice Honor to increase your roll by 2. This can’t, however, turn the failure into a success.

WATCHING EACH OTHER’S BACK Whenever one does their job, everyone can rest easy. If two or more allies are Multitasker, they both get a +1 to one of their rolls for every 2 levels the Professional has obtained.

SKILL FOCUS (Any, 3) At first level and every level other up, Professional receive 3 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skill. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level but are applied after Skills have been bought by the Character.

SKILL ADEPT This character has a knack for skills. All Advanced Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all Skill Suites. This stacks with other Skill Adepts.

PRIMARY DRAWBACK

The Professional is a man of reputation and so, when it is besmirched, it affects him gravely. For every 5 Honor you lose, lose an additional 1.

RANGER

The Ranger’s strengths rely mostly in their survival skills, making them excellent to have in the wilderness but they also gain a bonus to their movement that allows them to out pace others during skirmishes.

VITALITY DIE

d8

SKILLS & MASTERIES

Rangers receive 1 free purchase of the Survival Skill Suite.

ARCHETYPES ABILITIES

QUICK FOOTED The Ranger relies on being able to cross great swaths of land quickly, chasing down their prey. At first level and for every 2 levels he’s obtained, the Ranger increases his base movement rate categories by 1 foot. He can't increase it again until all other movement categories have been increased in a like manner.

A first level Ranger can choose Stroll/Crawling, Walking, Jogging, Running, Sprinting. If he chooses Walking, his Walk becomes 6 ft / second. At level 3, he can chose Strolling/Crawling, Jogging, Running, or Sprinting, but not Walking. After he's increased all by 1 ft, he can go back and increase his Walk again.

PUT YOUR HEADS TOGETHER For survival, communication is key and doing so quickly is often extremely important. When using each other as Assets, all allies of the Ranger have their Investment Time start at 1 hour instead of 2 hours and 45 minutes.

SKILL FOCUS (Survival, 5) At first level and every level up, Rangers receive 5 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skills from the Survival Skill Suite. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level but are applied after Skills have been bought by the Character.

SKILL ADEPT This character has a knack for skills. All Advanced Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all Skill Suites. This stacks with other Skill Adepts.

PRIMARY DRAWBACK

A Ranger finds armor restricting and irritating: all Armor Advanced Trainings are 2 CrP more expensive per Tier (Tier 1: 10 CrP, Tier 3: 22 CrP).

SAGE

The Sage gets some of the most expensive and cerebral skills for free but also, because of his intense training, he has the ability to instantly reroll any skill he chooses.

VITALITY DIE

d4

SKILLS & MASTERIES

Sages receive 2 free purchases of the Lore Skill Suite

ARCHETYPE ABILITIES

MEMORY TRAININGThe Sage’s training doesn’t just revolve around studying but also on how to study, allowing them better recall of information than those without such mental discipline. The Sage may reroll 1 Int, Wis, or Cha based Skill Check for 15 Stress. They may do this multiple times but each time they do so between opportunities where they can heal Stress costs them double, however, they also lower this Stress gain by 1 for every 2 levels they’ve obtained.

FRANK DISCUSSION You can often get more out of a discussion than you can simply thinking about something. When used as an Asset, the person receives a +1 to their Skill Check and an additional +1 for every 3 levels the Sage has obtained.

SKILL FOCUS (Lore, 5) At first level and every level up, Sages receive 5 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skill from the Lore Skill Suite. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level but are applied after Skills have been bought by the Character.

SKILL ADEPT This character has a knack for skills. All Advanced Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all Skill Suites. This stacks with other Skill Adepts.

PRIMARY DRAWBACK

The Sage has spent most of his time buried in study and so may take a bit longer to react to reality: they always roll an initiative die 2 sizes larger.

THIEF

The Thief has the widest variety of skills, picking from a uniquely built suite, rather than a predetermined one on top of their other free skills.

VITALITY DIE

d4

SKILLS & MASTERIES

Thieves receive 2 free purchases of the Streetwise Skill Suite

Gain Thieves Cant Mastery for free

ARCHETYPE ABILITIES

THIEF’S TRAINING At first level and every 2 levels they obtain, the Thief receives 4 free purchases in Advanced Skill from the list found below. This can be doubled up into a single skill or spread between any number of them.

Thief's Training Skills

A thief may choose from the following skills:

- Appraisal (Specific): - Escape Artist

- Camouflage: - Hiding

- Climbing: - Law (Culture)

- Disarm Trap: - Scavenging

- Distraction: - Move Silently

BROTHER/SISTERHOOD When you know others have your back and you have theirs, it’s much easier to keep your calm. Everyone increases their Stress Threshold by 5. This bonus increases by 3 for every 3 levels the Thief has obtained.

SKILL FOCUS (Streetwise, 3) At first level and every level up, Thieves receive 3 free skill purchases. These can be distributed between any Advanced Skill from the Streetwise Skill Suite. These free purchases may not be doubled up on in the same level but are applied after Skills have been bought by the Character.

SKILL ADEPT This character has a knack for skills. All Advanced Skills have their cost reduced by 1 CrP. They also gain a 10% discount to all Skill Suites. This stacks with other Skill Adepts.

PRIMARY DRAWBACK

Thieving is not an Honorable profession. A Thief loses 5 Honor should their profession become publicly known.

WILDERMAN

🜂 Advanced Rule

The Wilderman is a savage by most standards. They tend to be those raised in the wild by feral creatures, or those mountain men that retreated to the frontier so long ago that they’ve lost the rounded edges that civilization originally bestowed on them.

VITALITY DIE

d12

SKILLS & MASTERIES

Wilderman receive 2 free purchases of the Survival Skill Suite

ARCHETYPE ABILITIES

ANIMAL AFFINITY The Wilderman has a natural connection to the beasts. As such, he can form bonds with them quicker than humans. A Wilderman can use one of his followers at anytime to attract an environmentally appropriate animal companion instead.

You may never gain more than 1 animal companion at one time.

ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONING Being outside in all seasons and weather, hardens the Wilderman. He considers himself up to 40 degrees warmer or colder than the surrounding climate.

ONE PACK The Wilderman knows that you either survive together or die separately. Anyone can use anyone else’s Honor Dice, however they take Stress equal to what they roll on it.

ANIMAL FRIEND Being around animals allows you to really get in their head and communicate with them on a level that civilized people just can't. This ability allows the Wilderman to get into a Conflict with any Natural Animals to move their disposition from Hostile to Neutral or from Neutral to Friendly, though not from Hostile to Neutral in one Conflict. This is only temporary, however, ending a few hours after first contact.

ENDURANCE TRAINING A Wilderman is used to running and jumping for hours on end and gain a -1 to their Encumbrance for every 2 levels obtained.

SKILL FOCUS (Survival Skill Suite) At first level and every level up, Wildermen receive a free purchase in the Survival Skill Suite.

PRIMARY DRAWBACK

A Wilderman finds no comfort in society and they often find themselves ill-at-ease in the company of others: all races are considered 2 steps down the Racial Preference table.

Though much study and natural talent, Caster Archetypes can channel the Painted World, using its power to alter reality.

Caster Archetypes rely more on clever applications of spells rather than outright doing damage and so can often subtly shift the playing field in their favor. They rely mainly on Intellect and Wisdom since they need a high Stress Threshold as it is extremely stressful to shape Weird.

AUGUR

🜂 Advanced Rule

An Augur is one who watches the stars. The times and seasons are linked to the swirl of constellations overhead and the ways of magic. Those that watch them carefully can harness their power. An Augur gains bonuses based on the passage of time, making them change with the times.

VITALITY DIE

d4

SKILLS & MASTERIES

Augurs receive 1 purchase of the Lore Skill Suite. On top of this, they also receive 2 free purchases of Navigation Advanced Skill and 1 free purchase of Mathematics and Arcana Advanced Skills.

ARCHETYPE ABILITIES

Daily Omen Boon
Day of the Week School
1st Animism
2nd Calling
3rd Charm
4th Glamour
5th Investiture
6th Occult
7th Sortilege

ASTRUM IUNGO As part of their training, Augurs are taught how to harness the magic that drifts down from the stars and constellations. This gives them a steady pool of Spell Points whenever they cast a spell.

At first level, all spells the Augur casts have 7 SPs. This can be spent to modify the spell that they’re casting. It does take a moment to summon the astral forces, so casting a spell takes 3 seconds.

They increase this by 1 SP for every other level they obtain.

LECTIO COTIDIE At the beginning of each day, the Augur reads the signs and divines which of the astral winds, and thus which Weird Tradition, is most dominant on that day. This happens in a cycle based on the days of the week.

When casting a spell from the Tradition linked to the day, the Augur receives an extra d4! SP to spend on that spell. This extra dice is increased by 1 size for every 3 levels they obtain.

If you lose track of the day of the week, you’ve lost track of the stars and don’t gain the bonus for that day.

Weekly Omen Boon
Week of the Month Category
1st Shape
2nd Range
3rd Origin
4th All

SIGNUM SABBATI The Augur knows each week brings a new fate and with it, new boons. The Augur gains an additional bonus of 1 SP whenever casting a spell that applies to the particular Rudiment. This is increased by 1 SP for every 5 levels they’ve obtained.

So, for instance, if this week is associated with Shape, roll on the Shape Rudiments Table found in Chapter 12: The Weird. If you roll, say Chain, all Chain spells you cast gain an additional SP.

If you lose track of which week, you’ve lost track of the stars and don’t gain the bonus for that week.

VESTIBULUM OMEN The calends are a special time, when the moon is new and the stars are able to shine; unfiltered, they empower the Augur. The Augur has a pool of 3 Honor Dice that they can use for spell casting anytime during the month. This pool is increased by 1 Honor Dice for every level they’ve obtained.

This pool refreshes on the first day of every month.

If you miss the first day of the month, you’ve lost track of the stars and don’t gain the bonus for that month.

LIBRO DEIBUS An Augur keeps a Book of Days where they store their spells. They gain 9 Rudiments of their choice at 1st level and an additional Rudiment every other level.

SKILL FOCUS (Arcana & Navigation) At first level and every other level up, Augurs receive a free purchase of the Arcana and Navigation Advanced Skills.

PRIMARY DRAWBACK

Augurs are extremely superstitious since everything is controlled by fate and the stars. Bad luck means a bad fate. They take 1 Stress every time they roll a 1 on a d20.

They also find other types of Weirdshaping strange and so are unable to take another Caster Archetype as their Secondary, however, they are able to double down in their Primary.

Augur Doubling Down Benefits

ASTRUM IUNGO

This starts at 7 SP base and is increased by 1.5 SPs (rounded down) per level.

SIGNUM SABBATI

This is increased to 1 additional SP for every 3 levels you’ve obtained.

LIBRO DEIBUS

This is increased to 12 starting Rudiments with a new one every level.

MAGE

🜂 Advanced Rule

The mage is one that allows himself to be buffeted by the astral winds and so channels great power but also is in great danger. The mage has the most raw power of the Caster Archetypes but it could backfire on him.

VITALITY DIE

d4

SKILLS & MASTERIES

The Mage receives the Skills & Masteries of his Secondary Archetype.

ARCHETYPE ABILITIES

WILD MAGIC CASTING The Mage is able to channel the power of the stars, harnessing it and creating magical energy. While doing so the caster must stand still and he glows with light, being illuminated by a column that reaches above them. This light is equivalent to a candle’s brightness.

After 7 seconds, the Mage gains their Spell Points. Unlike other Archetypes of this type, however, a lot is left up to chance. The Mage rolls randomly for the Shape, Origin, and Range of the spell and d4! SP that they can spend on the Effect.

They also gain an additional d4! “free” SP that can either be spent on the Effect, or to modify what they rolled on the tables on a 1 to 1 basis.

When considering Drain, the Mage only has to worry about the Effect’s Base Drain and so, essentially, gets the other Rudiments for free. As long as he has more Spell Points than Drain, he can keep the spell cast.

So, for example, a level 3 Mage finishes channelling and casts Flashbang. He rolls randomly and gets Circle, Double, and Aura, He rolls d8 and gets a 5 the Effect. He rolls his free dice and gets a 3. Since he’s casting Flashbang, he doesn’t want it to be an Aura (since he’ll be caught in it to), so he spends 2 of his free points to move it to “Near”, and then uses the final point to give him 6 SP so he can actually cast it.

Flashbang has an Interval of 5 Seconds, so he subtracts 3 from 6 when he casts the spell and then, after 5 seconds, does so again to essentially recast it. As long as you have SPs you can keep a spell active.

You can also suffer weirdburn from keeping a spell up too long: if your spell’s Drain is greater than your current SP, the spell is still cast, but you and everyone within 200 ft takes 1 Stress for every point you’re over.

Going back to the above example: if you have 9 SP, and you keep the spell up for 15 seconds, you and those within 200 ft take 4 Stress ( 20 - 3 - 3 ). Should you continue to keep the spell up, you’d take an additional 3 Stress every 5 seconds.

It is recommended that even though you don’t technically get those points until after that 7 second duration, that you roll everything ahead of time and figure out what you’re going to cast ahead of time. The GM is not obliged to stop the count for you if you haven’t been spending those 7 seconds wisely.

You can stop shaping at any time, however, you take Stress equal to the amount of SP you have left - Weird is a powerful primal force and once unleashed, it is not stopped without cost. You also cannot cast or keep up a spell and Channel. This doesn’t remove those SP but the Wizard does lose 1 SP every 6 seconds.

Channelling in Armor

Wild Magic Users (Mages and Wizards) both draw their power from the stars. As such, anything that gets between them and this, makes channeling more difficult. While this is negligible while wearing clothing, armor, being a mite bit heavier, does slow down Spell Point acquisition.

  • Light Armor increases channelling time by 5.
  • Medium Armor increases it by 10.
  • Heavy Armor increase it by 15.

WILD SURGE CONDUIT The Mage puts himself more at danger than other casts but is able to experience greater power. If the total number of SP from channelling is greater than 4 + level, a Wild Surge occurs.

In addition to whatever happens with the spell, it is also recast. The new version, however, is Circularly Shaped at Full Range and with an Origin of either Aura or Far, as the caster sees fit. They also take Stress equal to how much they were over.

EMPOWERED CHANNELING A Mage relies on an innate understanding of the flow of magic through his body and overtime he can increase its effectiveness.

Not starting at first level but happening after every level he's obtained, the Mage can either increase the size of any 1 of his dice by 1, or decrease her channelling time by 1, down to a minimum of 3 seconds.

She may also, indepentelly, decrease her channel time by 1 but this costs an amount of CrP equal to X, down to a minimum of 3 seconds.

ASTRAL FULCRUM There is nothing between the Mage and the raw Weird and that allows her to force what others can't. The Mage can 10 Stress in which case they gain all their SP in the first second. This is in addition to the normal Fallout.

However, they still need to complete the channelling: if they don't, they recieve an additional 10 Stress. As they become more powerful, however, they learn how to midigate that danger, lowering the Stress inflicted by 1 for every 4 levels they've obtained.

SPELL LIST A Mage gains 6 random Rudiments at 1st level and an additional Rudiment every 4th level.

INNATE UNDERSTANDING While a Mage has no formal study, they do gain some sort of understanding on the workings of magic, should they choose to care. They can purchase the Arcane Advanced Skill for half cost.

PRIMARY DRAWBACK

The Mage rejects martial prowess as a role and so all weapon masteries cost 3 CrP more per Tier (Tier 1: 11 Crp, Tier 3: 24 CrP).

They also find other types of Weirdshaping strange and so are unable to take another Caster Archetype as their Secondary, however, they are able to double down in their Primary.

Mage Doubling Down Benefits

SKILLS & MASTERIES

Double Down Mages gain 2 purchases of the Arcana Advanced Skill.

WILD MAGIC CASTING

Increase all channelling dice to d4!s

WILD SURGE CONDUIT

Increase your Wild Surge threshold becomes 5 + (level * 2)

EMPOWERED CHANNELING

This ability now starts at first level. Your free dice automatically increases every 3 levels. This is in addition to the normal increase.

SPELL LIST

Increased to 8 starting Rudiments + 1 new one every level

RUNEGALDER

Unlike other magic-users, the Runegalder seals magical power in his bond, allowing him to not risk his body when working with supernatural forces. This allows him to cast quickly and consistently but limits the amount and flexibility of his spells.

VITALITY DIE

d6

SKILLS & MASTERIES

Runegalders receive 1 free purchase of the Lore Skill Suite as well as an additional free purchase of Literacy in their native language and the Arcana skill.

ARCHETYPE ABILITIES

VANCIAN CASTING The Runegalder chains the power of spells to various runes that he then invests, sealing them with his blood until he’s ready to release them.

Every 24 hours, the Runegalder can seal 3 spells. He can also bind an additional spell for every 3 levels he’s obtained. This means that he may cast those spells at any time by simply speaking the rune they’re linked to, once prepared.

Speaking the rune releases it from it’s binding so speaking the same rune again before he’s resealed it will not recast the spell - the spell’s power is gone.

He may cast a spell multiple times per day but he’ll need to bind each instance of the spell to a different rune.

Speaking a rune in this way doesn’t affect the Runegalder and so he ignores Fallout to himself.

He may also unseal a rune without actually casting it but he is not able to immediately reseal a new rune right after.

GRIMOIRE This is the Runegalder’s spell book and keeps the spells that he binds to runes. Unlike a normal spell book, however, the spells are scribed in meteorite ink and blood that seals their magic power in the text itself. Essentially, the Runegalder’s Grimoire does the channeling latently for him.
