In that case, it would be perfectly reasonable to just call for a single Jumping (or Monster Craft) Check. If the players want to do some Preparation or use any of the other tools at their disposal, they can.

Or, if there is a time crunch but it is so narrow players really wouldn't have the time to prepare, like having to jump the chasm while a horde of brigands with bows are closing it, you might also just default to the single roll: no need to break out these rules in that case.

In these cases, the Failure Threshold of the Check would be 1, meaning a failure is a failure, but you can spice it up by having the jump almost make it but now the player is just barely hanging out: however much time you want to spend on it.

Multi-Layer Checks

Let's say that you're trying to deduce facts about bears before you go to fight one. The thing is, there is a lot to know about bears and your character probably isn't going to know all of it, so making a single Check is too binary while making multiple Checks is too tedious.

In steps the Mutli-Layer Check.

In this case, the GM would assign Difficulty Dice to the different facts about bears based on how esoteric the knowledge is. He would then roll 1 d20! and all of those Difficulty Dice. You would only roll a single Check and the compare that to the difference totals to see if you recall those facts.

So, for instance, the knowledge that they habernate is no common but it's not uncommon, do the GM assigns that d6!. The knoweldge that they're afraid of fire is common, so he rolls d4! for that and the knowledge that they're sacred animals to the local indigious tribe is pretty rare because said tribe is extremely secretative so that would be a d20!.

You roll your Monster Craft and get a total of 16. The GM gets a 13 for the d20, a 4 for the d4!, a 5 for the d6! and a 1 for the second d20!. That means the totals are 17, 18, and 14 respectively. This means your character hasn't really been around bears to he doesn't know that they hibernate or that you can scare them with fire, however, he does recall over hearing some of the wanderers in the local tavern talk about how the animal was sacred to the local tribe and killed one of them after he wounded one of the creatures.

DIFFICULTY

Difficulty is a dice that is added to the Skill Check based on things that might be going on at the time to either help or hinder your success.

So, for example, finding food to eat while living off the land is much easier in a forest than it is in, say, a desert. In the forest, the players would receive a +d8! to their roll while in the desert the other side, the Obstacle, would get a +d20!. This is in addition to the base d20!, by the way.

Obstacles can have static, variable, shrinking, circular, growing, or "universal" difficulties.

STATIC means that the dice pretty much stays the same, outside of player interaction. This is often used for one off checks and not really used as the main part of a Skill Challenge because, let’s face it, doing the same Check over and over again isn’t that interesting.

VARIABLE means that the Obstacle has multiple Checks associated with it but that the difficulty variables wildly over time. So, for instance, a rock wall that is slippery at the base, then has a section with a lot of handholds, and finishes with an overhang, would be three separate Checks, the first with a d12! difficulty for the wall, the next with a d4! for the players, and the final with a d10!, again for the wall.

SHRINKING means that it starts high but then the dice shrinks as time passes, often becoming static at a certain point. This is when the threat becomes less and less severe, and I would use this sparingly and with other types of Obstacles, but it can represent the fact that leaving a place is often easier than getting in.

GROWING is the opposite of shrinking: it starts low and then increases as time passes, again, sometimes becoming static at a certain point. This is used to represent threats that continue to grow, often times when there is time pressure.

UNIVERSAL This is a term for an Obstacle that will go off at sometime but won't be directly faced by the players. It represents a chance encounter, such as running into someone randomly, or a stroke of bad luck, like bad weather. Unlike other Obstacles, players won't make Checks directly against it but any Failure (or Success) against another Obstacle in that Challenge adds a like amount of Failure (or Success) to any Universal Obstacles.

CIRCULAR means it starts at a difficulty, grows to a certain difficulty, and then shrinks down to its original difficulty, rinse and repeat, ad nauseam. It can also start shrinking, if you’d like. This is often used as patrols, like guards and such, but also a monster stalking an area would be represented by this type of Obstacle though you would have it be a bit more random to represent that unpredictability.

So, for instance, a guard patrol that makes a loop around the house would be a good example of a Circular Obstacle. When the patrol is furthest away from where the players are breaking in, the difficulty to not be detected by them is 0 so they add nothing to their roll, but when the guards are right on top of the players breaking in, the difficulty is +d20!. If it takes them 7 minutes to get from that furthest point to the players, that means every minute, the difficulty for the players increases by 1 dice size.

But, as the guards finish their circlate, heading back to the furthest point away from the players, the difficulty shrinks by 1 size per minute.

"Pausing" the Skill Challenge

The players don’t always have to be making Skill Checks during a Skill Challenge - they should only do so when it makes sense.

So, (using the above example) if the patrols aren’t very good and the guards get too far away from the players to reasonably hear them, no Check should be required.

But that doesn’t mean that time stops: if the players wait long enough, the guards will return and Checks will need to start up again.

FAILURES, HARD & SOFT

Failing a Check doesn’t automatically mean that you’re instantly screwed: Failing a single Move Silently Check doesn’t result in the guards catching you. In Bonfire, there are soft failures and hard failures.

Soft failures are when you fail a single Skill Check. How much you failed by is added to the Failure of the Obstacle you’re making the Check against and your Stress, while how much you succeed by due to help is just added to that Failure.

When that Failure goes over that Obstacle’s Failure Threshold, you get a hard failure for that Obstacle. Hard failures are when something bad actually happens. In this case, it does result in you getting caught by the guards, or it results in your falling off the wall and taking damage. Even after a hard failure, you can sometimes try again, like in the case of falling off the wall.

Failure doesn’t diminish during the Skill Challenge but it does reset for a new one.

Soft Failure in the Narrative

Soft Failures don’t mean that the Skill Challenge grinds to a halt while the players keep reattempting that Skill: instead it should represent the players coming closer to danger.

For a quick example, let’s say that there’s an adventurer, we’ll call him New York Smith, York for short, who is attempting to jump a chasm, which has a Failure Threshold of 10.

He rolls his Check but fails by 7. In this case, he obviously jumped but also didn’t make it. What does that mean? Well, New York didn’t quite make it but managed to grab the ledge as he fell, so he didn’t fall to his death but he isn’t safe either: the GM can make a roll for another Check to see if he can scramble up the sides, but that probably won’t be a Jumping Check.

ACTIVE & PASSIVE OBSTACLES

Another thing to consider is whether or not the Obstacle is Active or Passives.

PASSIVE means that whomever you’re up against doesn’t realize they’re up against you. This is the, for example, the watchman doing his nightly rounds or the river you have to cross.

ACTIVE means that whomever you’re up against realizing something is amiss and is now actively working against you. This doesn’t mean you're caught: it just means the person is on high alert.

Inanimate objects can also become “Active” though. While not the most appropriate term for it, it still represents a dangerous situation that suddenly occurs that makes failure more deadly, such as having your safety line snap while climbing.

BECOMING ACTIVE AND PASSIVE Passive is the default state for an Obstacle to be in, so you don’t really need to do anything special.

A Passive Obstacle becomes Active when you fail a Check against it.

Active Obstacle adds the amount of Failures it has to its Check, making it that much harder to succeed against it.

An Active Obstacle goes back to being Passive if you succeed at a Skill Check without any help (outside of Honor).

Staying Active

Now, most NPCs will stay Active for 1d4! hours unless they have a Characteristic that affects how diligent they are, but what about players? A person, NPC or not, gains 3 Stress for every hour they remain Active, so yeah, your players can remain ever vigilant but they'll be mental wrecks in a week or so.

What about if the players want to come back to try again? They can with any Active penalty they gained diminishing by 3 for every hour the Obstacle is Passive.

STRATEGIES

Stress Dice

Much like in a Social Conflict, your character is probably going to get Stress Dice. Note that, unless it says otherwise, that dice is a d6!.

When any of these tools note that you roll a Stress Dice, if you don’t have one, you simply gain one that then waits in the wings to be rolled the next time you roll a tool. You can gain multiple Dice this way without rolling them.

At the end of Challenge, you roll all Stress Dice and add it to your Character’s Stress.

ASSETS

These represent static pools of knowledge or information that you can pull from. So, for instance, a book on the subject, or a library are examples of an Asset but also an old friend who used to be a ranger could give you a few pointers so could give you a bonus to the Navigation Check you’re going to have to make to find those ruins.

Basically, anything you can think of that might apply might be an Asset you can draw on.

Assets add their Skill Rank to your Check, however this happens slowly based on that Asset's Time Investment.

For each period of the Time Investment you spend with the Asset, you gain a +1 to one of your future Checks, up until the Asset's Rank.

So, you go to your old ranger friend to get information about the local area. You know he happens to be a talker, so you know it’ll take you at least 2 hours (his Time Investment) to start to get anything useful out of him so you decide to spend the day with him, spending about 8 hours there.

Now, your friend doesn’t remember as much as he used to so his Navigation is Rank 3. After spending 8 hours with him, you get a +3 to your Navigation Prep Check. If you have stayed 6 or 7 hours, you would have still gotten that +3, while if you had stayed for 2 hours, you would have only gotten only a +1.

You don’t automatically know the Rank or the Time Investment of an Asset.

Another benefit of Assets is that they allow you to do multiple Preparation for a single Skill Check and the same Asset can be used to Prepare for multiple different checks. A library, for example, could allow you to Prepare for both a Monster Craft and History check.

Assets can also be increased and expanded upon as well, increasing its Rank. A good relationship with a contact might give you information quicker, donating to the local library may increase its selection, or hiring excavators to dig up a ruin may unearth more artifacts that help you decipher that ancient script.

There may be some special cases where an Asset will take care of itself but you may have to check back on it, such as Snaring in the forest. You set your trap and then a day or two later, you can go back and check it to see if you caught anything - in the meantime, you can get other work done.

Using Other Players As Assets

I think it's completely reasonable that players would want to use each other's characters as Assets and why shouldn't they? So, in this case, the Time Investment is set at 2 hours and 45 minutes - the character's Intellect * 3 in minutes. This means that a character with an Intellect of 13 has a Time Investment of 2 Hours, 6 Minutes.

GMs should also feel free to reward players who sit there and talk things out and plan by awarding the Asset bonus as well, even if they don't spend a full hour+ planning.GMs should also feel free to reward players who sit there and talk things out and plan by awarding the Asset bonus as well.

Assets & Equipment Based Skills

Some skills are only going to be useful if you have the proper equipment or the right Asset. For instance, if you’re not out in the wilderness, you can’t really use Snaring or if you don’t have the proper tools or a woodshop, Maintenance won’t do you any good. This will need to be handled on a case to case basis.

EQUIPMENT

Your kit can really pull you through in a pinch.

Players are assumed to be using any and all equipment that would help them with a check and you can choose to have one or more of these pieces of equipment to give you, in that moment, a reroll one of one your dice (taking the better of the two). You can have multiple pieces of equipment apply but the reroll can only be redeemed once per Check.

On top of this, if the gear you’re using has Traits that applies, you add any of those applicable bonuses to whichever roll you keep.

For the first redemption of this bonus between Maintenance Prep Checks this comes with no penalty but every time after that, the tool degrades, giving it a -1 regardless of whether you succeed or not. While players are assumed to be using all equpment that might be useful without having to specifically state as such, if a player did point out how a piece of equipment is being used to help them, they're automatically considered to have made a Maintenace Check before using it if they have that Skill.

You can use faulty equipment (ones with a negative modifier), since something is better than nothing. This still gives you a reroll but it’s on 1 dice lower (again, keeping the better of the two).

HELPER SKILLS

Let’s say that you’re tracking someone in the wilderness. You have Hunting at Rank 4 and Endurance at Rank 3. Seems like being able to move quickly over a longer period of time, should help you catch the guys and it does.

If you have another Advanced Skill that you think might help you, you can add it for the normal Stress Dice penalty and roll a Stress Dice.

This may seem like it is nearly identical to Preparation, and they are very close. The difference is that Preparation is a general thing that applies to a Skill Check you’re going to make in the future, while using a helper Skill is in the moment and is specific to the scenario. You can use both at the same time, since the help Skill gives a bonus and Preparation gives a reroll.

Skill Mobbing

For GMs, note that Helper Skills are how you handle Skill Mobbing, where everyone just overpowers a roll by all rolling against it. Instead, only one person rolls and only those with an applicable Advanced Skill and willing to take that Stress Dice add their Rank to help out.

MULTI-TASKING

Let’s be realistic here: you’re probably going to end up trying to do two things at once, like climbing a wall and doing so quietly.

If that’s the case, you’re going to have to “split” your d20! into smaller dice and assign those to each of the Checks you’re trying to make, because your attention is divided. The total max value of the dice can never exceed 20 but it can be lower than it. The other side will still be rolling full d20!s against you.

So, if you’re climbing a wall and trying to do so quietly, you’d have to make a Climbing and a Move Silently Check. You could split it like so: d12! for Climbing and d8! for Move Silently, or d10! for Climbing and d10! for Move Silently, or d12!+d4! for Move Silently and d4! for Climbing.

Or you could just say “screw being quiet” and roll a d20! for Climbing and take a 0 for Move Silently. In this case, the GM would just roll against your Skill Rank. So, if you choose to ignore Move Silently but have a Rank 4 in it, the GM would roll their dice, and you can hope they don’t roll higher than 4.

Either way, besides this, it works like a normal Check

Helping Others

It feels good to help people and Bonfire is all about group cooperation. The fighter helps the skill monkey survive combat and the skill monkey helps the fighter not look like an idiot while doing detective work.

And how you help other characters will really depend on the situation. Perhaps your Preparation can be used to help another person hide or perhaps you have a bit of knowledge that they don’t.

Really, this will be done to what feels right in the moment but this note is here to draw attention to someone helping you as an Asset and someone adding their Rank to yours with a Helper Skill, and how they’re different.

And the difference is time. If you have plenty of time to coach someone while they’re climbing a cliff face, you’d be an Asset and nobody would take a Stress Die.

But if you’re being chased by the guards and it’s a matter of seconds or minutes, you’d add a Helper Skill and both of you would need to take the Stress Die.

Note that if the skill monkey is also trying to climb the cliff face and coach as they go, that would be considered a d10! worth of effort for Multi-Tasking, though you don’t have to actually roll to see if you help.

PREPARATION

Preparation is anything your character does to help a specific Skill Check that will be made in the future (even if that future is 2 seconds from now). Note that this doesn't have to be a Check you make: it can also apply to an ally's Check (if it makes sense).

Usually, these only take a couple of seconds but can vary widely depending on the circumstances. Throwing a rock is a matter of moments while constructing a gilly suit will take a lot longer.

As long as there is time, there is no chance of failure or, if the players have plenty of time, Preparation just happens. Mark what you did for later in the Skill Challenge.

However, if there is a time crunch or a chance of failure, Preparation works like a normal Skill Check.

Either way, you only get one Prep Check per Advanced Skill that applies for each upcoming Check, unless you have Assets but remember that they do take time.

That means that if you know you're going to have to make a jump, you can use Acrobatics to stretch, Endurance to do a few practice sprints to the edge, and Sports (long jumping) to remember techniques all to prep for the same Jump check.

When you redeem Preparation that you’ve readied, you can reroll one of the dice that was rolled for the Check. This means either the base dice or the difficulty dice for either you or the Obstacle.

Planning & Action Phases

While it isn’t entirely black and white, it’s helpful to think of Challenges as composing two phases: planning and action; the laying out the plan and then the heist.

Planning is gathering intel, getting your team and equipment together, and planning your route of attack. This is where you’ll use Preparation, Taking Your Time, and Assets mostly.

Action phase is when you’ll be doing a lot of the Checks and Stress, as well as equipment and companions - using what you learned in the Prep Phase to help you get through the sticky parts.

But don’t get too hung up on separating these ideas though. Even during the heist, you might find it worth your time to sit on your heels and take your time while doing some Preparation as there will almost certainly be problems that crop up that you need to adjust to.

RUSHING IT

On the flipside, if you’re in a hurry to get the job down, you can just rush it. This subtracts 50% from the estimated time but gives you a -5. Like Taking Your Time, this can be done multiple times in a row to half the time again but it also increases the penalty by 1.

Failures don’t consider this -3 while determining the extent of your failure and success means you bought yourself some more time: removing the amount you succeed by, with the -3, from the Failure on one of the Obstacles.

TAKING YOUR TIME

The other thing that you can do is take your time and really try and do the job well. Doubling the time for your Check gives you a +6. This can be done multiple times in a row to gain a further bonus but each time lowers the bonus by 1, down to +0. Regardless of how long you take your time, you always only roll 1 Stress Dice.

So, if it would take you 15 minutes to search a room, you could take 30 minutes instead and get a +6, or 60 minutes for a total of +11 ( 6 + 5 ).

WAITING IT OUT

By doing nothing, you can calm your nerves and let who you’re facing do the same. This can be by either finding a shadow to hunker down in or finding a spot in the wall where you can rest while climbing.

Using this tool allows you to half the current Active penalty. You can also take points from that Active penalty and add them to the Failure against that Obstacle, though you can’t push the Obstacle above its Failure Threshold. You do roll 1 Stress Dice either way.

This may or may not work on an inanimate Obstacle but you need to use your best judgement.

SKILL DESCRIPTIONS

Skill Name Base Cost Stats
Athletics 41 Str/Con/Dex
Acrobatics 5 Dex
Climbing 7 Str

Escape Artist 7 Dex

Monster Craft 8 Int/Wis

Performance 5 Wis/Cha
Persuasion 5 Wis/Cha

ATHLETICS SKILL SUITE

This suite covers all things that requires physical prowess and, to a lesser extent, pure manual dexterity.

ACROBATICS This covers your characters ability to stretch their body, do flips and cartwheels. This allows the character to vault fences without slowing down or roll to avoid falling damage.

Check To Not Slow Down
Speed Difficulty
Walking -3
Jog -4
Run -5
Sprint -6
Check To Reduce Fall
Penalty Reduction
-2 -10 Ft
-3 -20 Ft
-5 -50 Ft
-8 -60 Ft
-13 -70 Ft
-21 -80 Ft
Per -5 After Add. -10 Ft

CLIMBING This skill covers climbing and repelling up and down walls of various heights and textures.

Difficulty should be based on height, with about every 40 ft increasing the difficulty by 1. Textures should also play a major factor in not just how tough the check is but also how many checks need to be made for a given wall.

So, if there’s a wall, where the base is stone at a 45% slant for 20 ft, then it moves to close knit stones for another 40 ft, and then finally to a wood overhang for just 5 ft, and then to a wooden wall for 10 ft, there would be 4 Climbing checks in this order: Trivial, Challenging (Average for base but because it’s 40 ft, it gets bumped up 1), Challenging, and Easy.

DISARM TRAP It takes nerves of steel to be able to cut the right wire or trip the trap in such a way that the least bad thing happens

Disarming a trap takes a base of 30 minutes if you don’t want to just set it off. If you’re in a hurry, you can half that time but you increase the difficult by 1 each time you do so. So, reducing the time to 7 minutes, would bump a Trivial trap up to Average in difficulty.

A failure indicates that you set the trap off accidentally.

ENDURANCE Through training, a character can push his body past the limits of his base physical ability. The Rank of this Skill is the number of seconds between taking damage while Running or Sprinting.

If a character is not trained specifically in this Advanced Skill, default to their Athletics Skill Suite Rank.

ESCAPE ARTIST This allows the character to escape bonds and restrictions and is always rolled opposed, either against the Rope Use skill of the person who tied them or against the quality of the manacles or binds the person was put in.

The character can make a straight Average check, not to break the bounds or get free, but to instead move his body to an advantageous position.

JUMPING You need to cover a distance without touching the ground: jump.

For every point you scored under what you needed, you travel either 2 ft horizontally or 1 ft vertically.

Jumping from a stand still is an Average check, while doing so with a running start is an Easy check. Add 1 to your roll for every Level of Fatigue your character has.

SPORT (specific) This covers the actually playing of a specific sport as well as an in-depth knowledge of the game’s rules and famous players and techniques. If it becomes a plot point, the GM should feel free to make this skill apply to only certain positions, like pitching or shortstop.

Move Silently Speed
Dice to Roll On Speed
d20! Crawling/Strolling
d12! Walking
d8! Jog
d4! Run
0 Sprint

MOVE SILENTLY When you want to move silently, you’ll want to use this skill. This involves being able to feel your way along and compensate for creaks.

This is always an opposed check vs any potentially listener’s Listening, with a failure indicating that the listener has heard something suspicious, though the person attempting Move Silently may not be aware that they were detected.

SWIMMING This skill allows a character to not drown in water. Without at least basic training in this skill, a character can’t attempt to swim with simply an Athletics check.

The difficulty of the check is determined by the water (or other liquid, I don’t judge) you’re attempting to swim in, though simply trying to float on your back and letting the current take you reduces the difficulty by 2, though it is risky because you could get pulling into an aquifer and drowned that way or get pulled over a waterfall.

LORE SKILL SUITE

This suite covers general knowledge, which is mostly academic in nature. Most of it is pretty heavy stuff but the basics are second nature or stuff that’s been picked up here and there.

ADMINISTRATION While they’ll never inspire the awe or respect that other leaders do, people who oversee the day to day functions of an organization keep the lights on so that others can make the speeches.

Administrators can make an Average skill check to gain a clue about an item the party might need on their adventure, or a Challenging one to retroactively remember that they did buy an item back at the market for just such an occasion.

Each of these checks they make increases the difficulty of the next one by 1 step.

ARCANA The science of magic is an oft studied but little understood branch of Lore that requires a deep knowledge of the nature of the Painted World.

With this skill, someone can identify a spell, point out needed regents and processes for ritual castings, detect if something is magical, or even detect if a spell has been cast in an area, and have a chance of finding out what it was.

All of these, except for the last two, are Average checks, with detecting whether or not a spell was cast in an area is Trivial + 1 for every day since the casting, or to detect what specific spell it was, Challenging + 1 for every day since the casting.

HISTORY Everyone knows certain large events, but few can tie those events into an overarching narrative and understand their effects on later events.

The History skill allows a character to not just recall events but also to link them to the present day, to certain traditions and rituals of a culture, or the behavior of certain members of a culture, giving insight on how to proceed.

LANGUAGE (specific) A character receives this skill for free in their native tongue at double their Rank in Lore and it allows them to speak and be understood by others with skill in that language.

Checks are only made when timing is critical, such as communication in a battle, or when understanding is key, such as when debating foreign policy.

If one of the characters is in a Social Conflict with another in a tongue that’s not their native one, that person can only bring in as many Characteristic Die per round as he has Ranks in that Language.

Additionally, when two native speakers are in a Conflict, the one with the higher Language Rank gains Leverage (see Applicable Skills under the Leverage Advance Rule in Chapter 9: Social ). In case of tie, nothing happens.

The Lore Skill Suite can’t be used in place of a Language Check for tongues you don’t know unless you have the Language Skill in a related Language. Using a real world example, someone with the Language (Swedish) Advanced Skill couldn’t use the Lore Skill Suite to understand a person with Language (French) but could use it when talking to someone with Language (Norwegian) or Language (Danish).

LAW (culture) This skill covers the intricacies of the legal system, including landmark rules and common punishments for common crimes. A character can make their case or find loopholes to exploit the legal system.

A character’s Lore skill can only be used to substitute in for their native culture but not others. If the character does wish to branch out, his mastery of Law for that culture starts at 0, as he must learn everything from the ground up. Diving more into his own culture’s laws (buying this Advanced Skill for his culture) uses the Lore skill as base, as per usual.

LITERACY (language) Unlike other skills, this skill can’t be attempted unless you’ve specifically bought this Advanced Skill and it’s mastery starts at 0. That’s right; every character starts illiterate.

This skill allows a character to read and write in a language’s alphabet, giving them the power to pen books and poems, or passive aggressive notes.

MATHEMATICS While this may seem like just a skill that allows you to be able to juggle figures and add totals and calculate the area of a circle like a huge nerd, Mathematics has a more practical use: correctly guessing distances.

While you can try to eyeball how far away something is, an Average Mathematics check allows you to do rough calculations, giving you the ability to know exactly what penalty you’re going to get for using a ranged weapon or who’s going to be affected by the Area of Effect of a spell you’re going to cast.

MEDICINE With proper treatment and nursing, a wound that would lay you out for weeks, may only keep you down for a couple of days. This skill involves the knowledge of long term care, when bandages should be changed, which poultices will have the greatest effect, and what minor surgeries need to be performed.

A character with this skill can make a Check for a wounded person, added the Severity of any Wounds that he's treating to the opposing roll. So, if a person has a 5, 3, and 8 Severity Wound, he can make a Medicine Check vs d20+16 or he can choose not to treat the 8 Severity Wound and make a vs d20!+8. Success means that the person can take 1 day off the healing time for that Wound every time it drops a Severity.

So, a success against a 5 Severity Wound means that is was treated properly and takes 10 days to completely heal ( 4 + 3 + 2 + 1 + 0 ) instead of the normal 15.

You may also increase the Difficulty modifier by half again as much - if you succeed, you take 2 days off per Severity. So, if you're against a d20!+9, you can make it a d20!+14 ( 9 + ( 9 / 2 ) ) for that bonus.

Additionally, a Check vs the a Poison, Toxin, or Disease's Lethality allows character to reroll their save.

MONSTER CRAFT This Advanced Skill is under both the Lore and Survival Skill Suite but still counts as 1 skill, so you don’t have to buy it twice - they share their Rank. It simply represents the different ways that each Skill Suite approaches the craft.

Monster Craft gives you insight into the creatures that roam the Middle Realm. Starting with something simple, such as their name, and the progressively learning more and more about them, such as they’re are fundamentally two different types of Incorporeal Undead or that you can convince Demons to do things if you win a Conflict with them.

The knowledge should be fairly general - weaknesses or where they draw their power from, so it will never reveal anything meta such as what the monster’s attack or Vitality is but it can let you know if the creature is known for having a lot of Vitality or is good at hitting.

Each Monster Craft check starts as an Average Skill Check and answers one question the player has on a success but each successive check on the same monster increases the difficulty by 2. On top of this, for rare creatures or hard questions, the GM may up the Difficulty as she feels is appropriate.

NATURE This area of study covers the topography of the Middle Realm. It’s forests and rock formations and biomes. It helps predict whether or not it’s going to rain or whether the next summer is going to be a hot one.

Predicting what’s coming in the next hour is a Trivial check, with the difficulty increasing by 1 for each time you double the prediction window. So, detecting the weather in the next 2 hours is Easy, while doing so in the next 16 hours is a Hard check.

RELIGION (cult) This skill acquaints the character with a knowledge of cults, their common Covenants and Miracles, as well as their hierarchies, means of advancement and important members.

It also allows a character to gain a knowledge of their rituals and sacrifices, as well as the taboos of their clergy and how to appease their heavenly messengers and avenging angels.

The Religion Skill is taken for a single Covenant, but can purchased independently for different Covenants.

A character adds the tens digit of this skill to their chance of gaining Favor when making sacrifices to the god of that cult.

STREETWISE SKILL SUITE

This suite covers knowledge that a character might pick on the street or in the school of hard knocks. While Lore is book smart, Streetwise is street smart.

CURRENT AFFAIRS A character with this skill is well informed about the day to day affairs of regional powers and men and woman of importance, their dealings and alliances, as well as their hatreds. He can pick out celebrities and know how and why someone got rich and famous. They can also use this skill to guess the Honor category of someone by watching how people react to them.

Deception Check
Penalty Level Of Lie
0 White Lie
-1 Lie Of Omission
-2 Mostly True Lie
-3 Half Lie
-5 Mostly False Lie
-8 Absolute Lie
-13 Absolute Lie With Easy Evidence Against It

DECEPTION This covers all sort of deception, where you want the person to believe opposite the truth, or, to put it simply, when you want to lie to them.

The level of difficulty to pull off a lie is based on how much of what you’re saying isn’t the truth, strictly speaking. This is always opposed by either the other character’s Deception or Perception but only if the character has reason to suspect that you’re lying to them.

Even if you succeed, this isn’t a permanent way of changing their mind. New evidence presented to that person may cause them to rethink their opinion on what you tried to sell them so be careful about what falsehoods you spin.

FORGERY Mostly commonly used for creating fake currency, forgery is a skill that allows a character to reproduce something effectively and fool others. This skill acquaints the character with common forging techniques and knowledge with what possible agents will being looked for.

The forger must also have the appropriate corresponding Craft or Trade skill, so he can’t forge coins if he doesn’t have the Metalworking skill, though that’s within reason: a character forging an official passport with one at hand doesn’t need to have Literacy as he can just copy the letters, though he may also need to have Artistry (wood cutting) to create the heraldry on it, but someone trying to forge an official declaration from skratch does need to have the Literacy skill in that language plus Artistry (wood cutting).

Forgery is opposed by Perception, the applicable skill, or Forgery but only if the character looking has reason to suspect there’s something else. A lazy guard probably won’t check your passport too closely right before lunch, but a particularly astute one who’s on the lookout for a promotion will, thus granting him a check.

GAMBLING/GAMING This skill doesn’t give the character a gift for winning games, just that he knows the rules and knows the odds, which could in turn lead to him winning the game.

INTUITION The ability to understand people and get where they're coming form can help you figure out what will and won't work with them better. A Trivial Intuition check allows the character to get a feel for how open a person would be to a Conflict over something or what would be definite dealbreakers. It doesn't reveal any of their Characteristics or their strengths as it's more of gut feeling than anything.

Each check on the same person increases the Difficulty by 1. To gain this insight, they must either watch them for a total of 3 hours + 1 hour for every additional thing they wish to learn, or talk to them for 10 minutes + 5 minutes for every additional. You can speed up the learning process, but 1 hour or 5 minutes, respectively, but doing so also increases the difficulty by 1. This time doesn't have to be in one sitting or done purposeful and more represents the fact that the person making the check needs to be familiar with the person on some leve.

LISTENING While Perception handles the other senses, Listening has to deal with your character’s auditory senses. This goes beyond simply hearing something: listening allows the character to know when an otherwise innocuous noise is actually something to pay attention to though it might not always be apparent why at first.

Lock Picking
Lock Penalty Base Time Time Off
0 1 Minute 1 Second
-1 5 Minutes 5 Seconds
-2 20 Minutes 30 Seconds
-3 30 Minutes 1 Minute
-4 45 Minutes 5 Minutes
-5 1 Hour 10 Minutes
Per -3 After Add. +15 Minutes 10 Minutes

LOCK PICKING It takes a lot more know how then you might think to pick a lock. The amount of time it takes to pick any lock is based on your skill level and the quality of the lock.

Subtract the Time Off x how much you succeeded your check by from the Base Time.

PERCEPTION This covers four of the five senses that a character has: sight, touch, taste, and smell. Technically, your character is always receiving inputs from these senses but Perception helps filter out the most important ones. Can he detect if there are orcs in the nearby bush? Can she taste the hidden poison in her drink before she swallows? These are all Perception checks

Like Listening, sometimes Perception will help the character notice something that may be important, even if it’s not obvious why it’s grabbing your attention.

SLEIGHT OF HAND This skill covers all things that require you to do quick, delicate movements with your fingers. This may be slipping a card up your sleeve, picking a pocket, or doing cat’s cradle while bored.

TRAP FINDING This actually covers a lot more than simple detecting trip wires or arrow holes in a dungeon. This can detect pits and snares, as well as buttons disguised as bricks or switches hidden as sconces.

A character can sweep an entire room with a Hard check but a character may be awarded a modifier secretly by the GM if they point out 2 or 3 spots they want to pay extra close attention to if one or more of those places actually houses the trap. Obviously, you don’t earn that modifier if you just name everything in the room and the more specific you are with what you’re searching, the higher that modifier should be.

SURVIVAL SKILL SUITE

This suite covers everything that a character might need to survive in the wild; Knowledge of what plants to eat and the skills to hunt and breed animals.

BOTANY This gives a knowledge of what the herbs used in cooking, alchemy, and medicine look like in their natural environment and it allows you to identify their common uses.

Mostly, this is used for detecting poisonous plants, which is a Trivial check, but someone with the Medicine skill can also find any local plants that might help him in his cures with an Average check, lowering his Medicine check by 1 if succeeds.

Camouflaging Objects
Penalty Size
0 Fine
-1 Diminutive
-2 Tiny
-3 Small
-5 Medium
-8 Large
-13 Huge
-21 Gargatuan

CAMOUFLAGE This involves more than just ducking behind a crate or sliding into the shadow of a doorway; the skill of camouflage represents a character’s ability to blend into their surroundings, given enough time and patience. It also always them to help others hide more effectively as well.

Assuming that the character has time and equipment to do so, a character gains his skill percentage in Camouflage to his Hiding temporary. Additionally, under the same conditions, he can also give this bonus to other’s Hiding checks.

When used to hide something in plain sight, like a cart, building, or weapon, he may roll a check based on its size.

FIRE BUILDING Against the cold, lonely nights out in the wild, there is only the fertility symbols you carve for yourself and the roar of the fire. This skill allows you to build one of those things: the fire.

Under normal conditions, it takes about 30 minutes and a Trivial check to setup and light a fire, assuming you don’t have to go far out of your way to find the wood.

FIRST AID This gives the character a crude understanding of battlefield medicine: making splints and staunching wounds.

A character with this skill can make a Check for a person wounded in that last 30 minutes, added the Severity of any Wounds that he's treating to the opposing roll. So, if a person has a 5, 3, and 8 Severity Wound, he can make a First Aid Check vs d20+16 or he can choose not to treat the 8 Severity Wound and make a vs d20!+8. Success means that the person can take 1 level of Severity off those Wounds. So a 5 Severity Wound drops immediately to a 4 Severity Wound. You cannot go back and do a Check for a Wound that you skipped.

You have 30 minutes to preform First Aid Checks for a person, which each Wound taking 3 minutes to see to, if appliable. You may also increase the Difficulty modifier by half again as much - if you succeed, you hit 2 points of damage. So, if you're against a d20!+9, you can make it a d20!+14 ( 9 + ( 9 / 2 ) ) to heal 2 points of damage.

HANDLE ANIMAL (specific) This skill deals with the handling and care of a specific animal, from birth to the slaughter house. It also deals with training and common illnesses to make sure the stock is healthy and viril.

The base price of this skill is calculated towards domesticated animals. If the player wishes to learn how to deal with wild animals, this skill costs thrice as much to purchase.

HIDING This allows a character to make the most of a situation or environment to cloak themselves against prying eyes. This is always opposed by Perception, with the difficulty determined by the area. Character can also use this to instantly get an idea of how well they can hide in the given space.

MONSTER CRAFT This skill is the same as the Monster Craft under the Lore Skill Suite. Look there for details on it.

NAVIGATION Either using the stars or the position of the moons and sun, this character can track their way even through the most untamed wilderness without getting lost. It also allows them to tell the time.

Without proper equipment, a character can only give rough estimations of where they are, anchored on larger geographic feature (like mountains or rivers but not towns or roads) to the nearest 10 miles.

SCAVENGING There’s a gift in high speed appraisal. This is often used by those picking over battlefields for anything they could sell, but it’s also found a niche with adventurers who use it to find food and sustainance while traveling away from civilization.

A Trivial check tells a character which of two things considered is worth more. This can’t be used for coinage, but can be any other type of good. It also gives the character an idea of whether broken equipment can be reasonably salvaged.

This doesn’t give even a ballpark of what anything is worth but it only takes a few seconds of consideration.

SNARING This teaches the character how to properly create and place snares to trap smaller wildlife. It also gives some cursory knowledge on the best places to put them.

A successful Trivial check nets 1 lbs of usable game meat at the end of the day, with the amount you can catch increasing by 1 for each additional difficulty.

Hunting Check
Modifiers Condition
-8 Raining
3 Still Muddy Ground
1 Heavy Foliage
-3 A Day Difference
-5 A Week Difference
-1 For Each Day After A Week
1 Each Person In The Persued Party

HUNTING Most of the time, you’re not going to down your query in one go, and so the hunt is on as your watch for subtle signs of their passing. While this skill was originally used to hunt wildlife, it has been repurposed by wardens and bounty hunters trying to capture the most dangerous game.

The base for a Hunting check is Average difficulty, however, a lot of different factors play into a hunt. Each condition either raises or lowers the difficulty by the noted amount. These are not all the conditions that come into play but it should give you a good base line.

On a failure, the Tracker loses the trail for a number of days equal to the amount they failed by. They must double back and can try a second check after the time elapsed to see if they’ve found the trail again. Should they fail the second time, they’ve completely lost the trail.

If your query is actively trying to hide their tracks, it becomes opposed by the query’s Hunting skill.

USE ROPE Covering all kinds of knots and bindings, the Use Rope skill is pretty self explanatory, though it should be noted that you can also use this skill to get a sense of the tensile strength of a rope or how much you’re going to need for a certain job.

To keep your players on their toes, I suggest you make the check, not when they tie the knot, but when it’s tested.

TACTIC SKILL SUITE

Combat isn’t just about raw physical power, but more about how it’s directed and used. This Skill Suite deals with logistics and making the most out of what you have.

COMBAT STYLE (style) By studying the best tactics and how to fight in certain circumstances, a warrior can take advantage of his surroundings and combat styles emerge. Combat Styles can be anything but involve to parts: a situation and a metric. This situation is when the Combat Style is most effective. For instance, it can be “in the forest”, “fighting on rooftops”, “being outnumbered”, “being in a duel”, “fighting while prone”, etc.. Really anything (as long as your GM approves). The second part of the Combat Style is the metric is applied to. This can be anything you could normally specialize in. Both the situation and metric are selected at the time of purchase and cannot be changed.

If the situation is applicable, the character receives a +1 to that metric for every 2 Ranks of that skill he’s obtained.

So a character with the Combat Skill (unarmed fighting, attack) at 5 who gets into a tavern brawl gets a +2 to attack as long as he doesn’t draw his weapon and simply uses fisticuffs.

Having a high Rank in Tactics doesn't automatically give you Combat Style bonuses under all circumstances and buying this skill for the first time starts it off at Rank 0, instead of the Tactic Suite's Rank.

Distraction Check
Penalty Time
0 1 Second
-2 1d2 Seconds
-3 1d3 Minutes
-5 1d4 Minutes
-8 1d4! Minutes
-13 1d6! Minutes

DISTRACTION More than simply yelling “hey, look” at someone, the art of distraction is the art of holding people’s attention.

The amount of time that someone is delayed is based on the difficulty of the check and how bent on their current activity they are.

The time given below is the time between checks, however, each successive check gets 1 difficulty harder, with the same result. So, distracting someone for 1d3 minutes the first time is Average, but the next 1d3 minutes you’re trying to hold their attention is Challenging.

This skill is less effective when the person knows they’re in immediate danger. In this case, as long as they’re not actively engaged in melee with someone, the time is reduced to equivalent amount of seconds. So, a successful Challenging check only delays someone for 1d4 seconds instead. Each successive check gets 2 difficulties harder in these cases.

LEADERSHIP The difference between a leader and an administrator is that the latter gets stuff done and the former gets others to get stuff done but hooking into what they believe and how they view themselves. Assuming you have a willing audience, you may make an Average Leadership skill check vs a social characteristic you think the person or group might have. If you succeed the check and they have the characteristic you’re looking for (or close enough - you don’t have to be exact), you increase their Morale by a number of points equal to the maximum value of one of the dice of that characteristic. So, a 3d4 Trait will only net 4 points of Morale.

You can increase the number of characteristics you’re aiming for by increasing the difficulty of the check by a like number, but the audience only gains the bonus from the largest of the characteristics.

QUARTER MASTERING There’s an art to packing and making sure that everyone is well fed and prepared. If a the quartermaster is using a personal container of any kind, he adds 2S for each Rank he has in this Skill. Otherwise, he adds 1S per Rank. This also applies to any person he packs for.

RALLY When manure hits the windmill, no speeches or grand narratives will keep a person from bolting. Only the cold will of a competent commander can keep a battle from becoming a route. A captain who successfully makes a Check for someone who is currently over their Stress Threshold, heals that person a number of Stress equal to his Rank. This is opposed by the enemy captain, if appliable, and each Check against the same target increases the Difficulty by 1, regardless of whether it was successful or not.

Recruiting Check
Modifiers Location
5 Captial (pop +200,000)
2 Large City (pop +100,000)
1 Medium City (pop +15,000)
0 Small City (pop +8,000)
-1 Large Town (pop +1,000)
-3 Medium Town (pop +500)
-5 Small Town (pop +20)
-8 Wilderness

RECRUITING Knowing where to find the right person is a crucial skill for any long term expedition. A character with this skill can find a random person willing to hire on with a Trivial check in a number of days equal to their roll.

Now, finding specialists or someone with a certain skill is another matter. Every additional criteria adds 1 level of difficulty to the search.

Where you’re looking also makes a difference, as well.

This doesn’t guarantee that the person found will take the job or doesn’t have some serious issues, like a crippling fear of dogs: it only guarantees that they have the skills you’re looking for and that they’re somewhat interested in being hired on. Pay and comfort make a lot of difference to a prospective hire.

RIDING This skill teaches a character how to maintain their stability while on horseback and making them capable of feats of equine prowess.

The bonuses for this Skill are varied and many with the specifics spelled out in Chapter 10: Combat under the Mounted Combat section so they won't be listed here. Seriously, go check it out.

SIGNALLING This is the knowledge of how to communicate over long distances, either using semaphore, smoke signals, signal lamps, or horn blowing.

When using this means of communication, each side rolls a check based on how complicated the message is and how quickly they need to send it. Signalling is an ad hoc language with no grammatical rules or complicated tenses and so even at the best of times, only simple messages can be sent.

WARFARE The Warfare skill hands directing troops on the battlefield, weighing options and devising plans on the fly. Those with this skill can roll it to temporarily pause combat to ask one question and receive one answer from a specific member of the party, or to simply tell them something. On top of this, you can also use this, out of combat, to confer with players who’re characters are not present in the scene.

Checks start at Trivial but increase by 1 difficulty each time they’ve been rolled that combat.

Warfare also has additional benefits and uses that will be outlined in Crowns of Fire, the kindgom management and mass combat supplement for Bonfire Advanced.

TRADES SKILL SUITE

This suite covers the crafting and creating skills. While there are a wide array and breathe of professions, this list is pared down to those areas of knowledge where the common man and the adventurer overlap in their needs.

APPRAISAL (specific) It’s wise to know what something is worth before selling and buying it. This skill handles that and is taken for a specific type of good, such as books & scrolls, livestock, jewelry, armors & armor, and so on.

If a character has the appropriate skill covering the item he’s looking to sell/purchase, he can get within her roll, expressed at a percentage, of what the item is currently worth, with the Check based on how common the item is and how closely it relates to his skill’s focus.

Additionally, the character should get a bonus if he has any skill that’s applicable to the thing he’s purchasing.

ARTISTRY (specific) While some many not find the Fine Arts a worthy way to spend time, others may disagree. Artistry covers all artistic endeavors, including painting, sculpture, embroidery and anything else that is done for art’s sake.

COOKING/BAKING On the road, a hot meal can count for a lot. A character who has a hot meal subtracts 1 day off the amount of time it takes to heal their Stress per Stress, so, they’re able to heal 15 Stress in 120 days, instead of 105.

On top of this, a character can prep otherwise unpalatable or poisonous food in such a way as to make the most of it, though it is a Challenging check to do so, meaning they can stretch rations for longer.

Unless the character is trying to prep a feast worthy of His Imperial Majesty, basic daily cooking only requires a Trivial check.

CRAFT (specific) This skill covers any skill that makes something that isn’t noted here, such as carpentry, tailoring, basket weaving, pottery, etc.. The GM may adjust the price for a particularly difficult to master study.

LEATHERWORKING From the moment it leaves the beast to the moment the final touches are finished, leatherworking handles the process of making and crafting works from the hides of animals, including skinning and tanning.

MAINTAINCE The skill of tinkers and adventurers, this gives the person a general knowledge of easy and ad hoc fixes that can be done on the fly. The level of difficulty in repairing something is equal to the total penalty it gives, rounded up to the nearest dice size.

So repairing a spear with a -1 to Attack and Damage is Trivial (d4!), while repairing one with a -3 to Attack and Damage is Easy (d6!).

METALWORKING This covers the process of changing crude ore into a beautiful weapon, armor, or decorative piece. It also covers the construction and repair of more mundane things, like plows, but if you’re picking this skill up, I doubt you’re doing it to corner the farmer’s market.

MUSICIAN (specific) This covers the mastery of specific instrument, including singing. At the end of the day, the dulcet tones of a neatly played mandolin can ease the ache of a long day. A character who hears someone play an instrument subtracts 1 day off the amount of time it takes to heal their Stress per Stress, so, they’re able to heal 15 Stress in 10 days, instead of 15.

This doesn’t stack with others playing, however, and does no good if you’re in a stressful situation, like being hunted.

Unless the character is trying to serenade a queen, basic daily ditties only require a Trivial check.

PERFORMANCE This skill covers everything from making your case before a court or a stirring speech before charging into battle. On a success, anyone listening gains a temporary d4 Devotion to what the performer wants: whether that’s themselves or an organization or a case. If the Devotion already exists, the size is temporarily increased. Additionally, the Devotion dice size can be increased 1 for every extra level of difficulty the orator passes their check by.

PERSUASION You may think that the truth is powerful enough to carry your argument but you can be beat out by a master of deception. Persuasion is the skill of rhetoric and formulating the truth in such a way that make it the most convincing.

The level of difficulty to convince someone is how much evidence you can supply to back up your arguments. This is opposed by Deception or Persuasion but only if someone is trying to actively trying to deceive or convince the same person as you.

Even if you succeed, this isn’t a permanent way of changing a person’s mind. Others may lie more effectively than you can tell the truth and that may cause them to rethink their opinion on what you tried to sell them.

Persuasion Check
Factor Level Of Evidence
13 Amply Evidence Right At Hand, Backed Up By First Hand Experiance
8 Amply Evidence Availible But Not At Hand With Conviction, Backed Up By First Hand Experiance
5 Some Evidence With Conviction With First Hand Experiance
3 Some Evidence With Conviction With Only Rumors
2 No Evidence But Conviction, Or Vice Versa. Rumors Of The Truth
1 No Evidence Or Conviction, Rumors Of The Truth
0 No Evidence Or Conviction, No Rumors.
Social

Your character is a multi-faceted representation of a fictional persona. She has her hopes and her dreams, her strengths and her weakness. All of these add up to hopefully make someone that has a compelling story of victory over her flaws, or defeat from the same.

In game play terms, these are represented by 4 characteristics:

GOALS represent what your character is trying to achieve.

TRAITS represent what sets your character apart from other characters.

PASSIONS represent interests and things that get your character’s blood pumping.

DEVOTIONS represent their relationships, either with people, organizations, or otherworldly powers.

FLAWS are also considered social characteristics so they're back!

These characteristics will be provided dice that will be used in social conflicts addressed below and represents how strong it is, with the bigger the dice, the better it is.

GOALS

Characters can start with up to 3 Goals, but needs to have at least one at all times. They receive Experience and Honor, as well as increasing the other 3 social characteristics, as you progress along the path to completing them.

What does you character want? Why can’t they get it? These are the two fundamental questions that should be answered for each Goal.

Overlapping Characteristics

You may think you’re pretty smart by having a Trait and Passion both be the same thing so that you always get to roll them at the same time. However, consider that you’re putting your eggs in one basket and it would be worth it to vary it a little to cover more bases, allowing you to use them more often and perhaps leveraging characteristics to bring in others.

Ideally, they should include other party members and the overarching plot of the campaign.

These goals can be anything from the incorporeal (“I want to find a home” or “I want to deal with this anger inside me”) to the very concrete (“I want to find my father’s sword” or “I want to stop this invasion”).

The best goals are those that are measurable and obtainable.

Being motivated by a Goal allows you to push yourself beyond what you thought was possible. When a Goal applies to a Conflict, you lower the dice size of any Reprecussion Dice by 1.

Starting Characteristics

If you’re bringing in a new character to a new campaign, it’s highly probable that you won’t know what the game is going to be about, especially if the GM wants to keep it a secret.

It’s perfectly acceptable to leave your Goals, Traits, Passions, and/or Devotions blank until you’ve got your feet under you but you should have at least a few Medium term goals and your strongest Trait filled out relating to your character’s personal arch.

TRAITS

Trait Dice
Charisma Weak Weak Weak Medium Medium Strong
1 - 5 d4! d4! d4! 3d4! 3d4! 4d4!
6 - 7 d4! d4! d4! 3d4! 3d4! 4d6!
8 - 9 d4! d4! d4! 3d4! 3d4! 4d8!
10 - 11 d4! d4! d4! 3d4! 3d6! 4d8!
12 d4! d4! d4! 3d6! 3d6! 4d8!
13 d4! d4! d4! 3d6! 3d8! 4d8!
14 d4! d4! d4! 3d8! 3d8! 4d8!
15 d4! d4! d6! 3d8! 3d8! 4d8!
16 d4! d4! d8! 3d8! 3d8! 4d8!
17 d4! d6! d8! 3d8! 3d8! 4d8!
18 d4! d8! d8! 3d8! 3d8! 4d8!
19 d6! d8! d8! 3d8! 3d8! 4d8!
20 d8! d8! d8! 3d8! 3d8! 4d8!

Traits are things that stick out about your character. Things that people tend to notice about them or that the character defines his identity by. These can be something specific (“I have blonde hair”) or something general (“I have an intimidating demeanor”) or somewhere in between (“I’m an orc”).

Traits don’t have to be physical in nature. It could be how your character views himself (“I’m confident” or “I’m good at math”). They can also be something about your character that he just can’t explain (“I’ve always been good with dogs” or “I can read people easily”).

The sky's the limit when it comes to Traits, so go wild, though they can't have exceptions. So, "I'm an angry person" works but "I'm an angry person but I don't let it effect my work" doesn't.

You start off with 6 Traits of varying levels: 3 weak, 2 average, and 1 strong. These are represented by dice of varying size. How strong these Traits are depends on your Charisma. So, if you have a 13 Charisma, you gain 6 Traits - three at d4, one 3d6, one 3d8, and one at 4d8

While naturally Charismatic characters come out of the gate with strong personalities, as you adventure, your character will also grow and change, gaining and strengthening their Traits. This can be done by either increasing your Charisma, which also raises your Traits, or by buying Traits up directly.

Thinking of Traits

Thinking of Traits on the fly is hard. For new players, there's two ways of handling this: either picture a character from fiction you like or find interesting, and try to describe them. These are their Traits and you can crib off them to start with.

Or if you have no idea where to start or are just a risk taker, you can use the Trait Generator, which will give you a random Trait. These Traits may not always make sense but they can often serve as a jumping off point for your imagination.

You can find it in Chapter 9 on the Bonfire SRD

ASSIGNING YOUR TRAIT POINTS

If you want a little more control over your Traits, their strength and how many, instead of just accepting what's on the above chart, you can use your Trait points from Charisma to modify your Traits how you will. You start off with 6 Traits of varying levels: 3 weak (1d4 each), 2 average (3d4 each), and 1 strong (4d4). This is instead of what you would have gotten.

From there, you buy up your Traits using those points in the same way as if you were buying them up with CrP.

You can also then go back and further increase them with CrP but only after you're done using all your Trait Points.

INCREASING TRAITS WITH CrP

Trait Increase Cost
Weak (1dX) Medium (2dX) Medium (3dX) Strong (4dX)
Xd4 7 4 10 10
Xd6 6 8 10 14
Xd8 5 12 10 18
Xd10 4 16 10 22
Xd12 3 20 10 26

If you want to increase your Traits further, you can spend CrP to give them a boost. This represents your character spending time developing their personality rather than spending time learning other things. If you built your character in Basic and are now switching over to Advanced, you can refund your Trait buy ups to redo them, but only once.

Weak, Medium, and Strong Traits all cost different amounts to raise. Why? Well, in the Basic game, there was a very simple strategy to winning and we wanted to keep things simple so you could learn the basics. Now we're giving you the power to try different ways of convincing people so we needed to make sure the numbers made sense and that you weren't "wasting" your CrP were it wouldn't benefit you, so you'll notice that Weak Traits actually get cheaper the more you buy.

You can also buy new Traits for the base Xd4 price.

So, for example, if you want to increase a Medium Trait from 2d6 to 2d8, it would cost 12 CrP.

Please note that you can't buy a Trait past a d12

Starting Characteristics

If you’re bringing in a new character to a new campaign, it’s highly probable that you won’t know what the game is going to be about, especially if the GM wants to keep it a secret.

It’s perfectly acceptable to leave your Goals, Traits, Passions, and/or Devotions blank until you’ve got your feet under you but you should have at least a few Medium term goals and your strongest Trait filled out relating to your character’s personal arch.

RACIAL TEMPERAMENT

Your Racial Temperament also tends to come into play fairly regularly during social situations. Like a Trait, you can add its dice in an Appeal. But what is the dice size? Well, it's your Honor Dice.

So, basically, if your Racial Temperament applies, you get your Honor Dice that round. Pretty easy, pretty straightforward.

PASSIONS

What does your character do in their downtime? What’re their hobbies and what do they spend their time thinking about? These are their Passions.

You have a number of Passion Points from their Intellect that can be used to buy and increase your Passion for a subject. New Passions cost 12 points and start at a strength of 1. You can then spend 8 points to increase that by 1, but you can do this multiple times. You can also spend CrP as well in a like manner.

Once per Conflict, if your Passion applies, you can increase a single dice size a number of times equal to that Passions strength. This can be done at any time during a Conflict and you don't have to spend all the increases form a Passion at one time. You can do this once for every applicable Passion but you can't use multiple Passions on a single dice.

If you do spend a point to increase a die you've already rolled, you get to roll again, taking the second result, even if it's worse.

DEVOTIONS

The final aspect are the Devotions that your character has. What relationships does he have? What organizations does your character associate with? Is he religious and, if so, is his loyalty more to his cult or to his god? How does he feel about that thing?

Relationships between individuals don’t need to be reciprocal or even contemporary. A young fighter may be inspired by a girl who doesn't love him back or by a long dead king he greatly admires. These are still viable candidates for his Devotion.

Everyone receives two free Devotions: one to their character’s clan/family and another of their choice. Each Devotion comes with a "relationship verb" and the thing itself. So, his clan Devotion could be "Hate Clan" or "Have mixed feelings about Clan" or "Loyal to Clan"

Servant Archetypes gain an additional Devotion which is to their god or cult which is assumed to have a positive aspect (love, loyal, faithful to, etc.).

These Devotions start a 2.

Devotions are a more powerful driving force than other Characteristics, meaning that, if a Devotion applies, you automatically get 1 point for every point you have in it. So, if you approach a blood enemy, trying to convince him to help you, even if you’re being entirely reasonable, it’ll be much harder to do so.

BUYING NEW AND INCREASING DEVOTIONS

All new Devotions start at 1 and cost 4 CrP to purchase. From there, you can increase their size which costs 6 + (2 * your current Devotion). So, to go from a 2 to a 3 Devotion, it'll cost you 10 CrP ( 6 + ( 2 * 2 ) ).

FLAWS

Let's circle back to Flaws because they are considered part of your Social Characteristics, after all, they make up who your character is as well. You start with your Flaws giving you 1d4! + your current total Stress you have in Social Conflicts should you bring them in.

WHEN TO USE THESE RULES

These rules may not be appropriate to break out everytime two people talk to each other, or even disagree on something. If you think your character can make a compelling argument that would convince an NPC to change his ways or give him a discount, don’t bother getting your dice out.

Additionally, if the GM thinks that what the player is asking isn’t probable, they can turn them away at the door. Sure, it’s possible that the blacksmith with give you that sword for free, but is it probable? Absolutely not.

However, it is probable that he’s at least willing to give you a discount. The other person must also see a possible benefit to engaging with you.

So, if you have a Conflict over a discount, that gives him a window to upsell you if you lose the Conflict. That might be worth it to him, while just having him give you the sword for away for free results in no Conflict unless the fighter convinces the blacksmith that the town is going to be shortly overrun by a goblin horde and that he needs a better weapon to fight them off, perhaps the blacksmith would be willing to part with the weapon for free, or maybe, if he's particularly stingy, he'd be willing to lend it to him temporarily for free.

And so setting the stage for a Conflict is often helping the NPC see what they could possibly get from you should they win.

Another way to start a Conflict is to get a person to act on their Characteristics, such as provoking a very aggressive person to attack you, or getting someone who is a softtouch to give you money. In that case, you simply state that, based on what you know about the person, they should probably act this way. If you're actually correct, you can start a Conflict with them. If you're wrong, you lose 1 Honor.

So, for instance, you know that an NPC is a known liar so you want him to lie to make a bold faced lie in front of the king to out him as the enemy. You state something along the lines of "You know, I think this guy is just a compulsive liar that he'll try and get away with lying to the king". If that's correct, you start the Conflict.

But let's say that the NPC doesn't have a Trait, Flaw, or Passion that related to lying. Turns out, the man has a Passion for manipulation instead. He wasn't lying because he was a complusive liar, he was lying for a very specific purpose. In that case, you'd lose 1 Honor.

Other Reasons to Start a Conflict

There may be other reasons why you feel a Conflict is appropriate. This may be the case of a demon who forces his will on another’s demon or, in a more mundane case, in the case of someone who wants to tell the player a secret but also may not trust them entirely or doubt the wisdom of doing so.

There may also be certain circumstances where one person is forced into a Conflict, most often through magical means, but this is most often done as part of a plot point. More information is found in the Conflict as a Plot Point in Bonfire Advanced.

STARTING the CONFLICT

Most commonly, The characters have to decide what’s at stake; this is what they’re butting heads about and why they’re willing to put themselves on the line. More importantly, each side has to define what they want to happen to the stakes. If the stakes are high, this might change how much each side to willing to fight to get what they want or what tactic they’ll use to get it.

You also have to take into account what the other person is just straight up not willing to do. You can't convince a priest to desecrate the altar of his Divine, for instance, or someone to give away a family heirloom just because you want it. Additionally, both sides have to see some sort of benefit, should they win.

So, for instance, a blacksmith and a fighter want to get in a conflict over the price of a sword. That’s what’s at stake. The fighter wants it at a discount, the blacksmith wants to make a bigger profit.

If you're starting the Conflict because you're trying to get someone to act on one of their Characteristics, you don't have stakes in the same way. Instead, if you win the Conflict, they act on their Characteristic, if they win, they manage to restrain themselves and you might lose 1 Honor (plus any additional you may have ponyed up).

Your GM has the right to simply say that an argument wouldn't work against someone and simply reject letting you put certain dice into your pool. So, for instance, you wouldn't get a Leverage die for having a hostage while having a Conflict with an orc who really doesn't care about the hostage's life, or you won't be able to bring in your Trait "I'm a gentle soul" to convince the hardened tyrannt's heart by making a heartfelt plea for him to stop skinning all the children.

Non-Binary Outcomes

The standard Conflict is a winner-take-all affair but that’s not always going to be the case. Sometimes there is room for compromise, such as when you’re haggling or trying to get a raise.

In this case, the stakes are set at the max each side is willing to give. After that, when a player loses Advantage, they can move their max to be closer to the other side. If you do, you also gain a d8! Leverage dice.

If what you want and what they want becomes the same, the Conflict is over with the Honor split equally between the two parties.

So, for example, a fighter and thief are dividing up the reward. Both willing to get into a Conflict over the shares because it means they both can gain something, the stakes are set at a 30/70 split.

After a few rounds, the fighter loses Advantage. He says that he’s willing to concede to a 40/60 split, with the thief getting the 40, if he wins.

Note that if the fighter wins, the thief will get 40% of the reward with the fighter pocketing the rest while if the thief wins, he’ll get 70% while the fighter will only get 30%, so even if he loses, by compromising the thief gets more than the starting 30%.

If both get to the point where they’re both aiming for a 50/50 split, the Conflict is over and they divide the spoils evenly between them, both Honor and treasure.

PLAYING OUT THE CONFLICT

The Conflict is done in a series of back and forths called “rounds”, in which each person is trying to get the other person to back down. This involves an argument-counterargument structure. A round starts when someone puts forth an argument and ends when the other person feels they’ve countered it or they’ve had to concede, so a round can be multiple exchanges but is commonly only a single back and forth.

The side who didn’t start the Conflict starts with 1 point.

Points come in two flavors: Evidence and Appeals.

EVIDENCE

Evidence is facts: things that are true, that both people know are true. These are flexes in power: I’m the king and so do you a favor if you do this for me. It can also be things you know about the other person, or subjects involved: if you know that a person is caring or has a temper, you can use that against them.

Evidence gives you 3 points. Evidence is the surest way of convincing your opponent but it also tends to be more work: you have to know about your opponent and know their situation.

Generally, this is signalled by placing a finger up in the air or pressing it against the table.

APPEALS

Appeals are appeals to a person’s emotions, their sense of self, or their Honor. Traits often (but not always) used this way. It can sometimes be a jab at someone’s character or an insinuation of skill, through bragging about how good of a climber you are or maybe displaying your weapon in a threatening manner. It can also be how famous your character is.

Appeals vary in the number of points they get you. When presented against Evidence, the Appeal gives you as many points as dice.

If, however, you meet Appeal with Appeal, then each person rolls the dice assigned to it. The person with the highest total gets points equal to the number of dice but sets aside a d6! for Repercussions, while the other person gets nothing and sets aside a d8!. This makes this a sound move for very charismatic people but it is still risky.

This is signalled by placing the dice in front of you, or holding them up, though you’re not obliged to reveal how many or their sizes.

Tracking Points

Each side is responsible for their own points but to make it easier, you can use the E/A method.

Write an E and A on top of each other, and then draw a line between them. When someone presents Evidence, put a tally next to the E. When someone wins a round with an Appeal, note how many dice are added by the A. When you're totaling your points at the end just multiple the tallies next to E by 3 and add that to the sum of the numbers by A. This should allow you to quickly jot things down and keep them straight during the Conflict.

Here’s some areas you can use to Appeal to your enemy and what their corresponding dice might be:

HONOR Your standing can carry you through the day, even if your arguments are weak. The character with the highest Honor gets to apply a free use of their Honor die to their pool.

FAME The sad truth is that the more famous you are, the more people assume you know what you’re talking about. If your Fame is greater than your opponents by 25, add a d4. Increase this die one size for every additional 25 points you have above them.

STRESS When your opponent is overworked and they're at maximum whelm, it's much easier to get them to give in. You can redeem a d4! worth of Leverage for every Stress penalty your opponent has, however, you don't have to redeem all the d4!s all in one round and can spread them out over the course of the Conflict.

EQUIPMENT It may be the case that equipment can sway an argument. Often this is through imitation or torture, but gold can also persuade a hesitant sellsword or the right equipment might convince a thief to take on a risky job. A badge of authority may also win you some influence.

Equipment used for this purpose gains the character a base d8. Equipment that’s substandard or that’s being re-purposed from its original use (a knotted rope used to whip a victim or a broken glass bottle used to threaten someone) only nets a d4.

STAT SOCIAL DIE Having an exceptionally high Strength or Dexterity might be relevant to the situation. If that’s the case, add that Abilities Social Die to your pool.

APPLICABLE SKILLS You may roll an additional die for any applicable Advanced skill based on that Skill’s Rank. This chart is also used to determine the base size of the Passion dice for that Skill. Take the Rank of that Skill and round up to the nearest dice size. So a Rank 5 Skill would net a d6 dice while a Rank 14 Skill would net a d20.

But that is by no means a comprehensive list and plays should be rewarded for out-of-the-box thinking. Appeals start at a d4!, but this can vary. For instance, a very skilled swordsman with a lot of Advanced Training in his weapon of choice makes a more powerful Appeal than a rookie.

You can use the same Appeal multiple times during a single Conflict.

Characteristic as Evidence vs Appeals

There’s no hard rule that can be given of when a Trait qualifies as one over the other, but there are some guidelines.

Generally, if the person whose Characteristic is being used is not directly involved and they’re known by both parties, it is Evidence.

If, however, one of the people is involved in the argument, especially if it is defense, or you’re trying to bring in the Characteristic of someone that the other person doesn’t know, then it is considered an Appeal.

The GM can say no to a proposal if the counter argument doesn’t directly relate to the argument, so careful phrasing could limit what your opponent can do. This is usually the indication that the round isn’t finished yet and the person who was rebuffed can try a different tact or argument.

Bluffing, or in other words, Lying
